docs.title: Characters
docs.text:
Characters

In GHOSTBURN, you are a Ghost, someone whose digital identity has been erased. You live outside the system, doing work for your Medium, the one who reached out and helped you when your life was in shambles.

You didn't start out as a ghost. You had a life once. A career. A Background. But that old life went up in smoke when you got Burned. The street waits. It knows you, and it waits until you are at your most vulnerable. But before the street could take you, your medium found you and offered a deal.

You took it.

Now, you do the jobs your medium brings. It's a different kind of work than what the corporate knobs do in their glass towers, but it's important, and it needs to get done. Megacorp media labels people like you as the bad guys. They call you criminals. Killers. Punks. And they're not totally off the mark, but they miss the nuance of what you're doing, the benefits you bring to society.

You make a difference, or, at least, you try. Some people out there have no other options. You exist to fill that void. Invisible and deadly. A ghost.

docs.title: Cybernetic Augmentations
docs.text: Characters in GHOSTBURN can get cybernetic augmentations installed in their body.

docs.title: Mesh
docs.text: You have an attribute called Mesh which represents the limit on how much cybernetics you can cram in your body. All characters have a Mesh of 10, plus their Strength score, plus their Resilience score. For example, a character with a Strength score of 3 and a Resilience score of 2 has a Mesh of 15 (10 + 3 + 2).

docs.title: Mesh Cost
docs.text: Cybernetic augmentations have a cost in creds, as well as a a Mesh cost. You add up the Mesh cost for all of the augments you have to determine the total Mesh cost. Then you compare that value to your character's Mesh attribute. Your Mesh cost cannot exceed your Mesh attribute.

docs.title: Cred Cost
docs.text: The cost in cred for each piece of cyberware is equal to (Mesh Cost x Cyberware Level x 10,000). Cyberware that does not have a level is considered level 1 for purposes of this calculation. For example, a Datajack has a Mesh Cost of 1, so it costs 10,000 cred. Wired Reflexes 3, on the other hand, has a Mesh Cost of 14 (and it's level 3), so it costs 420,000 cred (14 x 3 x 10,000).

docs.title: Abilities
docs.text:
Abilities represent a character's body and mind. Each character is composed of the following abilities:

Ability Description Presence A combination of raw magnetism, artistic talent, and social insight Agility Reflects a character's quickness, reaction speed, and manual dexterity Strength A measure of a character's physical form and raw strength Awareness Represents a character's senses and insights Intelligence Indicates a character's education and critical thinking Resilience Mental and physical fortitude; resist injury and psychic burn Psi Represents a character's raw psionic ability

docs.title: Ability Scores
docs.text:
Each of your abilities has a number associated with it called an ability score. An ability score has a natural range of 1 to 5. Cybernetic augmentations and psionic mutations can increase your ability score (up to +3), for a maximum augmented ability score of 8. Each of your ability scores must be at least 1, except for Psi, which is 0 if you are not playing a psionic character.

Ability Score Ability Level Description 0 Incapable Completely incapable, non-functional 1 Weak Underdeveloped, marginally capable 2 Below Average Less capable than most, often struggles 3 Average Human average, sufficient for most things in life 4 Exceptional Better than most, a serious contender 5 Peak Human The best of the best humankind has to offer 6 Beyond Human Exceeds natural human limits 7 Superhuman Awe inspiring, breathtaking 8 Extraordinary Nearing limits of the animal kingdom, apex predator

Note: Ability scores above 8 are beyond player character capabilities and are provided to the GM to use as a basis for powerful enemies, such as constructs, and to show theoretical limits.

docs.title: Burn
docs.text:
Choose a burn for your character. Your burn represents a major event with such a negative impact that it made your old life untenable.

Burn Description Betrayed You were betrayed by someone you trusted so deeply that it shattered your world. Confined You were held against your will, but you managed to escape. False Memories You discovered that some of your memories were implanted in you, and you had to get out. Framed You were framed for a crime you didn't commit and had no choice but to run. Identity Swapped Your digital identity was swapped with that of a criminal and you ran. Key Witness You have key evidence of a major crime like a murder, coverup, or massive fraud. Lost it All You lost it all. Your family, your friends, your job, your residence. Everything. Gone. Left for Dead You were part of a tragedy with mass casualties. Somehow you survived. Made Enemies You did something to make some powerful people very upset with you, and you ran for your life. Past Exposed A dark secret from your past was exposed, and you fled out of shame or fear. Reputation Loss Your professional reputation was destroyed by your enemies, leaving you with nothing. System Shock You became privy to information that shocked your conscious and left you unable to continue. Test Subject You were an unwilling test subject in a scientific experiment, but you escaped.

docs.title: Hook
docs.text:
Choose one hook for your character. The hook you choose frames the lasting consequences of your burn and can be used by the GM to introduce story elements into the game that are related to your character.

Hook Description Angel You know you can't help everyone, but you've decided to use your skills to do what good you can. Honor Code You developed your own code of honor after the events of your burn, and you strive to uphold it. Hunted You are hunted by someone described in your burn, such as the megacorp where you worked. Owe a Debt You could not have come back from your burn without the help of someone to whom you now owe a debt. Reconstruct You are driven by the need to rebuild some semblance of your former power, wealth, or glory. Redemption You feel guilt over something related to your burn, and now you are working to redeem yourself. Revenge You lust for revenge against someone described in your burn, such as those who hurt you. Saboteur Your burn left you with a desire to cause as many problems as possible for those you perceive as enemies. Thrill Seeker You came out of your burn with the feeling that you're never really alive unless you're in danger. Truth Teller You are driven to expose corruption and criminality, and you want to publish your findings to the Net. Vigilante Your burn made you develop a moral code, and now you seek to punish those who break your rules.

docs.title: Character Creation
docs.text:
In this game, each player creates a character to play. As the player, you make all the decisions about your character, including their background, natural abilities, skills, and so on.

To create a character in GHOSTBURN, follow the steps below.

Step Seven Questions 1. Choose a Background What was your old life? 2. Choose a Burn and Hook How did you get burned, and what drives you forward? 3. Choose a Contact Who do you still know from your old life? 4. Buy Ability Scores What are your natural abilities? 5. Distribute Skill Bonuses What are your skills? 6. Starting Package What gear and augments do you have? 7. Finishing Touches What is your name? Next: 1. Choose a Background ❯

docs.title: 1. Choose a Background
docs.text:
Refer to the Backgrounds List and choose one for your character.

Your background describes who your character used to be and includes a culture, favored skill, and an additional benefit.

docs.title: Background Name
docs.text: Write the name of your background in the space labeled Background on your character sheet.

docs.title: Culture
docs.text: Your background gives you one Culture (Corporate, Milsec, Street, or Underworld). Write a +1 in the box next to your Culture in the Cultures section at the bottom of the character sheet.

docs.title: Favored Skill
docs.text:
Your background gives you one favored skill. Fill in the diamond symbol (◇) next to the skill name on your character sheet to indicate it as a favored skill, and write +1 in its skill bonus box.

[INFO] //Favored Skills

It costs fewer XP to improve favored skills and to purchase signature tricks for your favored skills than it does for non-favored skills.

docs.title: Additional Benefit
docs.text:
Your background also gives you an additional benefit, which varies from one background to another. Your background may give you a piece of Gear, a Cybernetic Augment, a Signature Trick, or even a bit of Extra Luck. Write the additional benefit on your character sheet in the appropriate area.

Next: 2. Burn and Hook ❯

docs.title: 2. Burn and Hook
docs.text:
Look through the list of Burns and Hooks and choose one of each for your character.

Your Burn is a pivotal event in your life. It helps explain why your character is no longer living the life described by their Background. Your Hook represents the lasting consequences of the burn.

Your background, burn, and hook should all tie together to show your character's story Like this: I am a [Background] who was [Burned], and now I am [Hook]. Example: I am a [Street Vendor] who was [Witness] to a murder, and now I'm being [Hunted] by the megacorp that wants to silence me.

Write your burn and hook at the top of your character sheet.

Next: 3. Contacts ❯

docs.title: 3. Contacts
docs.text:
A contact is someone you personally know and with whom you are on good terms.

You can call on your contacts periodically to see if they can help you. Contacts can provide information, goods and services, or even a place to sleep. However, contacts won't go with you to a second location, nor will they fight for you.

You start the game with two contacts, one of which you get to choose and one given to you by your GM.

docs.title: Free Contact: Choose One from your Culture
docs.text: Choose a contact that has the same culture as you. This person might be connected to your old life, they may have helped you when you got burned, or perhaps they even introduced you to your medium. Feel free to come up with a name and a few details about your contact. Write them down on your character sheet and share them with the GM.

docs.title: Free Contact: Medium
docs.text:
Your medium is the person who "discovered" you after you got burned. They used their power and connections to erase your digital identity on the Net, turning you into a ghost. Your medium also put you together with the other ghosts in your crew. The GM will use your medium to offer you jobs, to provide you access to black market, and to assist with other things you might need. The GM will tell you the medium's name so you can write it down on your character sheet.

Next: 4. Ability Scores ❯

docs.title: 4. Ability Scores
docs.text:
A character's ability scores reflect their natural, human qualities, such as strength and intelligence.

Ability Name Description Presence Force of personality, social awareness, and artistic ability Awareness Physical senses, insight, and abstract thinking Agility Quickness, nimbleness, balance, and coordination Intelligence Education, reasoning, quick thinking, and general knowledge Strength Physical strength and general athleticism Resilience Bodily fortitude, health, and willpower

docs.title: Distribute 17 Points
docs.text:
You get 17 points to distribute between your abilities. Only one ability score can be set to 5 at character creation. The rest must be 4 or less.

The higher the score, the greater the ability. Natural ability scores range from 1 to 5, as shown below.

docs.title: 7. Finishing Touches
docs.text: There are a few last things you need to do to finish creating your character.

docs.title: Luck Points
docs.text: You start the game with one Luck Point. Write a 1 in the space labeled Luck Points on your character sheet. Later in the game, once you've earned XP, you can purchase up to two more Luck Points, for a maximum of three.

docs.title: Derived Characteristics
docs.text: Your Health Levels, Mesh, and Stabilization DL are derived from your other ability scores.

docs.title: Health Levels
docs.text:
Your hit points are based on your Strength and Resilience scores. Calculate the hit points for your Health Levels as shown below. When a halving would result in a fraction, round up.

Health Level Calculation Healthy (Max Hit Points) (Strength + Resilience) x 5 Wounded Half of Healthy Severely Wounded Half of Wounded Death's Door Half of Severely Wounded

docs.title: Mesh
docs.text:
You have a derived attribute called Mesh which represents the limit on how much you can cybernetically augment your body.

Derived Attribute Calculation Mesh 10 + Strength score + Resilience score

docs.title: Stabilization DL
docs.text:
When someone uses First Aid on you, they use your [Stabilization DL] to make you [Stabilized]. Your [Stabilization DL] is based on your Resilience score, as shown below.

Resilience Score Stabilization DL 1 Extreme (32) 2 Severe (26) 3 Hard (20) 4 Moderate (14) 5 Easy (8)

docs.title: Name
docs.text: Last, don't forget to give your character a name and write it on your character sheet.

docs.title: Conditions
docs.text:
This is where you learn how to play the game.

When to Roll

docs.title: Agony
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition, effect, or injury causes you intense, unbearable pain, you are in [Agony].

Effect: All tricks you use have their DL raised by one and their outcomes [Downgraded]. Taking painkillers diminishes the effect of [Agony]. When you take painkillers, tricks still have their DL raised by one, but their outcomes are not [Downgraded]. The benefit of painkillers lasts until the end of the scene.

Removal: When the source of the [Agony] is removed, you lose the [Agony] condition. If you are in [Agony] due to an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the injury's Recovery entry, causes you to lose the [Agony] condition.

docs.title: Ally
docs.text:
Cause: When you achieve a Cool Success on certain specializations, you gain an [Ally]. If your trick was used on a [Group], one representative individual fills this role.

Effect: The target gains an [Attitude] of Friendly. As long as the target is an [Ally], they will help you. Beyond just following your instructions or fulfilling your requests, an [Ally] will take the initiative to provide assistance. They will try to protect you as best they can, use their skills and knowledge to your benefit, and warn you before you put yourself in danger or miss an opportunity.

Removal: If you (or any member of your crew) attacks your [Ally], the target loses [Ally]. When the scene ends, the target loses [Ally]\, but you can try to make them a [Contact] (with the GM's approval). This requires a basic Presence roll with a DL of Severe (26). If you succeed, you permanently gain the target as a [Contact].

docs.title: Bewildered
docs.text:
Cause: When a skill action, condition, or effect leaves you deeply and utterly confused, you are [Bewildered]. This counts as and replaces the [Distracted] condition.

Effect: Tricks used on you have their DL lowered by one and their outcomes are [Upgraded].

Removal: At the start of your turn, you lose the [Bewildered] condition.

docs.title: Bleeding
docs.text:
Cause: When an attack, trick, or effect causes you to lose blood, you gain [Bleeding]. You cannot have more than one instance of [Bleeding] at a time.

Effect: At the end of your turn, take 1 damage.

Removal: When you gain the [Stabilized] condition, you lose the [Bleeding] condition.

docs.title: Blinded
docs.text:
Cause: When an attack, condition, or environmental effect prevents you from seeing, you are [Blinded]. This condition replaces [Vision Impairment].

Effect: You cannot see. All targets have [Concealment, Total] from you. Tricks with the [Visual] keyword have their DL raised by one and their outcomes [Downgraded]. It is not possible to even attempt an action that is exclusively dependent upon sight, such as identifying the man in the bowler hat. You gain [Movement Restricted].

Removal: When the condition or environmental effect that caused you to be [Blinded] is removed, you lose the [Blinded] condition. In rare cases, this condition is permanent.

docs.title: Break
docs.text:
Cause: When a a person or situation pushes you to your limits, you [Break] and can no longer control your actions.

Effect: You attack, flee, or break down on the spot. If you attack, you target what you perceive to be the source of your ire, which could be a person, place, or thing. If you flee, you attempt to escape that perceived source. If you break down, you fall [Prone] and pour out your emotions. If a group is caused to [Break], individuals from the group represent all three reactions. If a character caused the target to break, the target's [Attitude] towards that character drops to Hostile. If the target is [Compliant] when they [Break], they lose [Compliant].

Removal: At the start of your turn, make a basic Resilience roll with a DL of Moderate (14). Success means you regain control and lose the [Break] condition. For NPCs, the GM should make a Threat roll using the NPC's Fort as the DL.

docs.title: Burning
docs.text:
Cause: When an attack, trick, or effect causes you to be set on fire, you gain [Burning].

Effect: At the end of your turn, take 3 damage.

Removal: When you (or someone else) spend 1 AP to put out the fire on your body, you lose the [Burning] condition, and you are [Prone].

docs.title: Cognitive Impairment
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or effect makes it harder for you to think, you have a [Cognitive Impairment].

Effect: Tricks that use Intelligence have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the condition or effect that caused [Cognitive Impairment] is removed, you lose the [Cognitive Impairment] condition. In rare cases, this condition is permanent.

docs.title: Compliant
docs.text:
Cause: When a person or group is compelled to perform actions under duress, they gain the [Compliant] condition. This condition cannot be applied to player characters.

Effect: The Attitude of the [Compliant] person or group shifts to Hostile. They follow your instructions, even if they go against their own self-interests, but they will not put their loved ones in harm's way. They will not attempt to escape or retaliate as long as you remain in the [Vicinity].

Removal: If a target suffers a [Break], they lose [Compliant]. Forcing the target to do worse and more dangerous things requires a basic Presence roll (GM's discretion), and Failure means the target suffers a [Break]. Forcing the target to put their loved ones in harm's way causes them to automatically [Break]. If you or your crew attack the target, they suffer a [Break]. If you leave the [Vicinity] for more than one turn, the target automatically loses [Compliant] and flees or prepares to attack upon your return.

docs.title: Concealment, Partial
docs.text:
Cause: You are partly concealed, making it harder for you to be seen by an observer. It is possible to have [Concealment, Partial] to one observer and not another.

Effect: Attacks made against you by an observer to whom you have [Concealment, Partial] have their DL raised by one. Attempts to locate you through sight alone have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When you become fully visible to an observer or gain [Concealment, Total] to them, you no longer have [Concealment, Partial] to them.

docs.title: Concealment, Total
docs.text:
Cause: Your entire body, including your gear, is totally concealed and cannot be seen by an observer. It is possible to have [Concealment, Total] to one observer and not another.

Effect: When someone to whom you have [Concealment, Total] attempts to use a [Visual] trick on you, their DL is raised by two and their outcome is [Downgraded]. Attempts made by the observer to locate you through sight alone automatically fail.

Removal: When you become fully visible to an observer or switch to having [Concealment, Partial] to them, you no longer have [Concealment, Total] to them.

docs.title: Confident
docs.text:
Cause: When you feel good about yourself and believe in your own abilities, you are [Confident]. This condition cannot be applied to player characters.

Effect: [Social] skills and tricks used on your have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the scene ends or when something happens to ruin your state of mind, you lose [Confident].

docs.title: Confused
docs.text:
Cause: When a trick, condition, or effect makes it hard to think, you are [Confused].

Effect: When you use a skill or trick that has the [Concentrate] keyword, raise the DL by one.

Removal: At the start of your turn, you lose the [Confused] condition.

docs.title: Cover, Full
docs.text:
Cause: Your body is fully behind a solid object, and you are in now way exposed, making it impossible to see you or make an [Attack] against you. It is possible to have [Cover, Full] to one observer and not another.

Effect: Attacks made against you by an observer to whom you have [Cover, Full] automatically fail.

Removal: When you become fully exposed to an observer or gain [Cover, Partial] to them, you no longer have [Cover, Full] to them.

docs.title: Cover, Partial
docs.text:
Cause: Your body is partly behind a solid object and partly exposed, making it harder for you to be seen by an observer or struck by an [Attack]. It is possible to have [Cover, Partial] to one observer and not another.

Effect: Attacks made against you by an observer to whom you have [Cover, Partial] have their DL raised by one. Attempts to locate you through sight alone have their DL raised by one. If you are hit by an attacker from whom you have [Cover, Partial], the damage is [Reduced].

Removal: When you become fully visible to an observer or gain [Concealment, Total] to them, you no longer have [Concealment, Partial] to them.

docs.title: Critical Condition
docs.text:
Cause: When you have sustained a [Life Threatening] injury and were subsequently [Stabilized] only to then fail your basic Resilience roll at the start of a scene, you enter [Critical Condition]. You can also gain [Critical Condition] as the result of Surgery or Cybernetic Installation that ends in critical failure.

Effect: At the end of each hour that passes, relative to you, make a basic Resilience roll with a DL of Severe (18). If you succeed, you gain [Stabilized]. If you fail, make a mark. If you accumulate more marks than your Resilience score, you advance to [Dying].

Removal: When you gain [Stabilized], you lose [Critical Condition]. Any marks accumulated from failed basic Resilience rolls are reset to zero.

docs.title: Dark
docs.text:
Cause: When an area lacks sufficient illumination, making it very hard to see, it is [Dark].

Effect: When you are in the [Dark], you gain [Movement Impaired]. Also, targets at [Close] range have [Concealment, Partial], and targets who are [Nearby] or farther away in the [Dark] have [Concealment, Total].

Removal: When an area is illuminated, it loses [Dark].

docs.title: Deafened
docs.text:
Cause: When a skill, trick, or condition prevents you from hearing, you gain the [Deafened] condition. This condition replaces [Hearing Impaired].

Effect: You cannot hear. You are immune to sound-based attacks. Skill and tricks with the [Vocal] keyword have their DL raised by one. You are unable to use skills or tricks that have the [Auditory] keyword.

Removal: When the effect or condition that caused you to be [Deafened] is removed, you lose the [Deafened] condition. In rare cases, this condition is permanent.

docs.title: Death's Door
docs.text:
Cause: When you are reduced to half your Severely Wounded value (or less) in hit points, you gain the [Death's Door] condition. This condition follows and replaces [Wounded] and [Severely Wounded].

Effect: You gain [Movement Restricted]. You are [Prone]. All skill actions have their DL raised by one. The first time you gain [Death's Door] during a scene, roll on the Injury Level Chart; see [Sustaining an Injury].

Removal: When you have more than half of your Severely Wounded hit points, you lose the [Death's Door] condition. You also lose the [Death's Door] condition if you advance to [Dying].

docs.title: Disfigured, Major
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or injury dramatically alters your appearance in an unnatural way, you gain [Disfigured, Major]. This condition stacks with itself and with [Disfigured Minor].

Effect: Persuade tricks have their DL raised by one and their outcomes [Downgraded]. Intimidate tricks have their DL lowered by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Disfigured, Major] is removed, you lose the [Disfigured, Major] condition. If you gained [Disfigured, Major] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Treatment entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Disfigured, Major].

docs.title: Disfigured, Minor
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or injury alters your appearance in an unnatural way, you gain [Disfigured, Minor]. This condition stacks with itself and with [Disfigured, Major].

Effect: Persuade tricks have their DL raised by one. Intimidate tricks have their DL lowered by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Disfigured, Minor] is removed, you lose the [Disfigured, Minor] condition. If you gained [Disfigured, Minor] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Disfigured, Minor].

docs.title: Distracted
docs.text:
Cause: When a skill action, condition, or effect causes you to become unfocused and momentarily lose track of what you were doing, you are [Distracted].

Effect: Skills and tricks used on you have their DL lowered by one.

Removal: At the start of your turn, you lose the [Distracted] condition.

docs.title: Drowning
docs.text:
Cause: When you are underwater and unable to breathe or hold your breathe, you are [Drowning]. If you are swimming and become [Unconscious], you automatically begin [Drowning]. If you are forced to go [Prone] while swimming, you begin [Drowning].

Effect: You lose [Prone] and gain [Movement Restricted] and [Off Guard]. All skills and tricks have their DL raised by one. At the start of your turn, take 5 damage and make a basic Resilience roll with a DL of Severe (18). If you succeed, you automatically [Move][[Nearby](/../Keywords/Keyword_Nearby)] towards the water's surface. If the water's surface was [Far] away, you are still [Drowning]. Otherwise, you break the water's surface.

Removal: If you break the water's surface, you lose [Drowning].

docs.title: Drugged
docs.text:
Cause: When a chemical interferes with your ability to move, speak, and think, you are [Drugged].

Effect: You gain [Cognitive Impairment], [Movement Impaired], [Off Balance], [Off Guard], [Speech Impairment], and [Vision Impairment].

Removal: At the start of your turn, make a [Basic] Resilience roll with a DL of Moderate (14). Success means you lose the [Drugged] condition. If you are still [Drugged] at the end of the scene, you lose [Drugged]. If you are given an antidote for the chemical affecting you, you lose [Drugged] immediately.

docs.title: Dying
docs.text:
Cause: When you are reduced to 0 hit points, you gain the [Dying] condition. This condition follows and replaces [Healthy], [Wounded], [Severely Wounded], and [Death's Door].

Effect: You are [Unconscious]. Make a mark. At the start of your turn, make a basic Resilience roll with a DL of Hard (14). Success means you gain the [Stabilized] condition. Failure means you make another mark. If you accumulate more marks than your Resilience score, you are dead.

Removal: When you gain [Stabilized], you lose the [Dying] condition. You have 1 hit point.

docs.title: Emotional
docs.text:
Cause: A [Social] skill action can move you so deeply that you become [Emotional].

Effect: [Social] skills and tricks used on you have their DL lowered by one. This condition manifests as an emotional change that matches the tone of whatever triggered it. You might become angry, melancholy, reverent, nostalgic, excited, or cheery.

Removal: When the scene ends, you lose the [Emotional] condition.

docs.title: Entertained
docs.text:
Cause: When you witness something funny or enjoyable as the result of a trick, you are [Entertained]. This condition cannot be applied to player characters.

Effect: Your [Attitude] is raised one level.

Removal: When the scene ends or when something happens to ruin your entertainment, you lose [Entertained].

docs.title: Fine Motor Impairment
docs.text:
Cause: When you have difficulty doing things that use fine motor control, you have [Fine Motor Impairment].

Effect: Tricks with the [Fine Control] keyword have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused [Fine Motor Impairment] is removed, you lose the [Fine Motor Impairment] condition. In rare cases, this condition is permanent.

docs.title: Foggy
docs.text:
Cause: When a lingering haze fills the air, obscuring people and objects in the distance, it is [Foggy].

Effect: Without some kind of imaging enhancement like [Clearview], it is impossible to identify targets at [Far] range (or beyond [Far] with a [Scope]) when it is [Foggy]. Targets who are [Nearby] have [Concealment, Partial]. Targets who are [Close] are unaffected.

Removal: When the fog thins or dissipates in an area, it loses [Foggy].

docs.title: Healthy
docs.text:
Cause: When you have more than half your maximum hit points, you are [Healthy].

Effect: You are healthy.

Removal: Lose at least half of your maximum hit points.

docs.title: Hearing Impairment
docs.text:
Cause: When you have difficulty hearing due to a condition or effect, you have [Hearing Impairment].

Effect: Skill actions with the [Auditory] keyword have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused [Hearing Impairment] is removed, you lose the [Hearing Impairment] condition. In rare cases, this condition is permanent.

docs.title: Hidden
docs.text:
Cause: When you successfully use the Hide skill action, you gain the [Hidden] condition.

Effect: You are [Undetected] and have [Concealment, Total].

Removal: When someone finds you, such as by using Search or you reveal your position by attacking, stepping out of cover, or making noise, you lose the [Hidden] condition.

docs.title: Immobilized
docs.text:
Cause: When you gain the [Unconscious] condition, you also gain [Immobilized]. You can also be [Immobilized] by certain tricks or conditions or by being bound, such as with rope.

Effect: You cannot [Move].

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Immobilized] is removed, you lose the [Immobilized] condition. If you gained [Immobilized] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Immobilized].

docs.title: Incapable
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition, effect, or injury renders you unable to act, you are [Incapable].

Effect: You cannot take actions or make reactions.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Incapable] is removed, you lose the [Incapable] condition. If you gained [Incapable] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Incapable].

docs.title: Inspired
docs.text:
Cause: When a trick or condition leaves you feeling like you're at the top of your game, you are [Inspired].

Effect: Skills and tricks you use have their DL lowered by one.

Removal: At the end of your next turn, you lose the [Inspired] condition.

docs.title: Jammed
docs.text:
Cause: When a trick or condition uses electronic interference to temporarily prevent a device from functioning properly, it is [Jammed].

Effect: The device does not function while it is [Jammed]. If the device was moving of its own accord, it stops. If it was flying, it lands safely on the first available surface and stops. If you are remotely controlling when it becomes [Jammed], you no longer have access to the device and may not control it until [Jammed] is removed.

Removal: When the device is moved beyond the range of the signal that is making it [Jammed], it loses the [Jammed] condition. At the end of a scene, if a device is [Jammed], it loses [Jammed].

docs.title: Life Threatening
docs.text:
Cause: When you sustain an injury that requires emergency treatment, without which you could could die, you have a [Life Threatening] condition.

Effect: You need immediate medical attention. At the start of your turn, make a [Basic] Resilience roll with a DL of Moderate (14). Failure means you take 3 damage. This stacks with [Bleeding].

Removal: Receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Treatment entry of the injury. causes you to lose the [Life Threatening] condition.

docs.title: Mouth Breather
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition, effect, or injury prevents you from breathing through your nose, you gain [Mouth Breather].

Effect: Stealth and Persuade tricks have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When you gain the ability to breathe through your nose again, you to lose [Mouth Breather].

docs.title: Movement Impaired
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or injury makes it harder to move, you are [Movement Impaired].

Effect: It costs 2 AP to [Move] to an area [Nearby] or to use a trick with the [Move] keyword. Athletics tricks have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Movement Impaired] is removed, you lose the [Movement Impaired] condition. If you gained [Movement Impaired] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Movement Impaired].

docs.title: Movement Restricted
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or injury makes it nearly impossible to move, you are [Movement Restricted]. This condition replaces [Movement Impaired].

Effect: It costs 3 AP to [Move] to an area [Nearby] or to use a trick with the [Move] keyword. You cannot make Athletics rolls.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Movement Restricted] is removed, you lose the [Movement Restricted] condition. If you gained [Movement Restricted] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Movement Restricted].

docs.title: Mute
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition, effect, or injury prevents you from speaking, you are [Mute]. This condition replaces [Speech Impairment].

Effect: You cannot speak, though you may be able to make grunts or other sounds. You cannot use tricks with the [Vocal] keyword.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Mute] is removed, you lose the [Muted] condition. If you gained [Mute] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose the [Mute] condition.

docs.title: Off Balance
docs.text:
Cause: When a trick, condition, or effect makes it harder to stay on your feet, you are [Off Balance].

Effect: When you are [Off Balance] and attempt to [Move] or use a trick with the [Physical] keyword, make a basic Athletics roll with a DL of Easy (8). If you fail, you do not perform the action and immediately fall [Prone].

Removal: If a lasting condition is the cause of [Off Balance], then you lose [Off Balance] when you lose that condition. Otherwise, you lose [Off Balance] at the start of your turn.

docs.title: Off Guard
docs.text:
Cause: When you are in a state of being unprepared for danger, you are [Off Guard]. Most people are [Off Guard] by default.

Effect: An [Attack] made against you has its DL lowered by one.

Removal: When you observe immediate danger or are alerted to its presence, you lose the [Off Guard] condition.

docs.title: Preoccupied
docs.text:
Cause: When a skill action, condition, or effect causes you to become unfocused and lost in thought, you are [Preoccupied].

Effect: Skills and tricks you use have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When [Preoccupied] was applied, a condition was given for its removal. Completing that condition causes you to lose [Preoccupied]. If you are still [Preoccupied] at the end of a session, you lose [Preoccupied].

docs.title: Prone
docs.text:
Cause: When you lay down on the ground or are forced down by a condition or an attack, you gain [Prone].

Effect: [Ranged] attacks made against you, except Point Blank Shot, have their DL raised by one. [Melee] attacks made against you have their DL lowered by one. On your turn while [Prone], you may spend 1 AP to stand up., While you remain [Prone], you are [Movement Restricted]. If you are swimming when forced to go [Prone], disregard the rest of this Effect and you begin [Drowning].

Removal: When you stand up, you lose the [Prone] condition.

docs.title: Raining
docs.text:
Cause: When a steady rainfall makes it difficult to see and hear, it is [Raining].

Effect: Targets in an area where it is [Raining] have [Concealment, Partial]. Tricks with the [Vocal] keyword have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When rainfall thins or stops in an area, it loses [Raining].

docs.title: Recovering
docs.text:
Cause: When you are still healing from an injury, you are [Recovering].

Effect: While you are [Recovering], tricks you use have their Difficulty Level raised by one.

Removal: At the end of the session, you lose the [Recovering] condition.

docs.title: Restrained
docs.text:
Cause: When you are unable to [Move] because something or someone is actively preventing you from doing so, you are [Restrained].

Effect: You are [Immobilized]. On your turn, you can spend 1 AP to try and escape by making a basic [Strength] or [Agility] roll (your choice). If an NPC has subdued you, use their Fort as the DL. If you are being [Restrained] by rope, handcuffs, or the like, the GM should set the DL, typically at Severe (26). If you succeed, you escape by slipping out or breaking free.

Removal: When you are released by whatever had you [Restrained], you lose [Restrained]. If attempt to escape and get a Success on your basic [Strength] or [Agility] roll, you lose [Restrained].

docs.title: Servile
docs.text:
Cause: When you unnerve someone so much that they will do anything to please you, they are [Servile]. This condition replaces [Compliant].

Effect: As long as the target is [Servile], they will follow your instructions and look for other ways to please you. You can give them one task to complete, and they will do it as best they can, even if it takes days.

Removal: To maintain the target's [Servile] condition, you must pay them a visit at least once a day until the task is complete. Otherwise, they lose the [Servile] condition. You may verbally release them from the [Servile] condition at any time.

docs.title: Severely Wounded
docs.text:
Cause: When you are reduced to half your half of your [Wounded] value (or less) in hit points, you gain the [Severely Wounded] condition.

Effect: You gain [Movement Impaired]. All skill actions have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When you have more than half your [Wounded] value in hit points, you lose the [Severely Wounded] condition. You also lose the [Severely Wounded] condition if you advance to [Death's Door] or [Dying].

docs.title: Shaken
docs.text:
Cause: When a trick, condition, or effect leaves you momentarily shocked by what you saw or heard, you are [Shaken].

Effect: Skills and tricks used on you have their DL lowered by one. Skills and tricks you use have their DL raised by one.

Removal: At the start of your turn, make a basic Resilience roll with a DL of Easy (8). If you Succeed, you lose the [Shaken] condition. If you are still [Shaken] when the scene ends, you lose the [Shaken] condition.

docs.title: Speech Impairment
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or effect makes it hard for you to speak, you have [Speech Impairment].

Effect: Skill actions with the [Vocal] keyword have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to have a [Speech Impairment] is removed, you lose the [Speech Impairment] condition. In rare cases, this condition is permanent.

docs.title: Stabilized
docs.text:
Cause: When you are the target of a successful First Aid roll, or you succeed on a basic Resilience roll to avoid Dying, you gain the [Stabilized] condition..

Effect: You gain 1 HP and lose the following conditions: [Bleeding], [Critical Condition], [Dying], [Traumatized], and [Unconscious].

Removal: After [Stabilized] takes effect on you, you lose the [Stabilized] condition.

docs.title: Stress
docs.text:
Cause: [Stress] is triggered by getting a Fade on certain tricks. You can have [Stress] from multiple sources at once, but multiple instances of [Stress] from the same trick do not stack.

Effect: At the start of your turn, make a [Basic] roll using the trick that triggered your [Stress]. Use the DL identified in the trick's Fade outcome. Failure means you trigger the Glitch outcome of that trick.

Removal: You lose the [Stress] condition if you fail the [Basic] roll and trigger a Glitch. On your turn, if you have [Stress], you can try to improve the outcome by using 1 AP to roll the trick again; if you get a Success or Cool Success, you lose the [Stress] condition. If you have [Stress] when the scene ends, you lose the [Stress] condition.

docs.title: Stunned
docs.text:
Cause: When a skill action, condition or effect causes you to have a momentary mental or physical shutdown, you are [Stunned].

Effect: You are [Immobilized] and [Incapable].

Removal: At the start of your turn, you lose the [Stunned] condition.

docs.title: Suffocating
docs.text:
Cause: When a condition or effect makes it almost impossible for you to breathe, you are [Suffocating].

Effect: At the start of your turn, take 5 damage and make a basic Resilience roll with a DL of Severe (18). If you fail, you fall [Unconscious].

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Suffocating] is removed, you lose the [Suffocating] condition.

docs.title: Suppressed
docs.text:
Cause: When enemy gunfire pins you down, making it harder to move and retaliate, you are [Suppressed]. A single target can only have one instance of [Suppressed] at a time. Multiple applications of [Suppressed] on the same target do not stack.

Effect: You gain [Movement Impaired]. When you make an [Attack], the DL is raised by one.

Removal: At the end of your next turn, you lose the [Suppressed] condition.

docs.title: Suspicious
docs.text:
Cause: When you sense that someone may be lying, hiding something, or mispresenting the truth, you are [Suspicious]. This condition cannot be applied to player characters.

Effect: If you have a [Friendly][[Attitude](/../Keywords/Keyword_Attitude)] it worsens to [Neutral]. [Social] skills and tricks used against you have their DL raised by one. If the person you are [Suspicious] of is using a Disguise or a Forgery, you may attempt to see through it. To see through a Disguise or Forgery, the GM makes a Threat roll for the NPC and uses the DL set by the outcome the player achieved on their Disguise or Forgery roll.

Removal: If the subject of your suspicions improves your [Attitude] to [Friendly], you lose [Suspicious].

docs.title: Traumatized
docs.text:
Cause: When you sustain an injury by rolling on the Injury Level Chart, you gain the [Traumatized] condition.

Effect: All tricks have their DL is raised by one.

Removal: When you are [Stabilized], you lose the [Traumatized] condition. If you are still [Traumatized] at the end of the current scene, you lose the [Traumatized] condition.

docs.title: Unaware
docs.text:
Cause: When you gain [Unconscious] or [Stunned], you also gain [Unaware]. You can also be rendered [Unaware] by other circumstances.

Effect: You are [Blinded], [Deafened], and [Off Guard].

Removal: When you lose [Blinded] or [Deafened], you lose [Unaware].

docs.title: Unconscious
docs.text:
Cause: When you gain the [Dying] condition, you also gain [Unconscious]. You can also be rendered [Unconscious] by certain tricks or conditions.

Effect: You are [Immobilized], [Incapable], [Prone], [Unaware], and [Unresponsive].

Removal: If you are [Dying], you must be [Stabilized] with at least 1 hp to lose the [Unconscious] condition. If another condition or effect caused you to become [Unconscious], and it has its own Removal, you must abide by it. If no other Removal is indicated, then at the start of your turn, make a [Basic] Resilience or Threat roll with a DL of Easy (8). Success means you lose the [Unconscious] condition.

docs.title: Undetected
docs.text:
Cause: If a person has not detected your presence, then you are [Undetected] by them.

Effect: When you attack a target for whom you are [Undetected], they are treated as [Off Guard] for that attack.

Removal: When you are seen or heard by someone, you are no longer [Undetected] to them.

docs.title: Unresponsive
docs.text:
Cause: When you gain the [Unconscious] condition, you also gain [Unresponsive]. You can also be rendered [Unresponsive] by certain special attacks.

Effect: You are [Mute] and cannot communicate in any way.

Removal: When the condition that caused you to be [Unresponsive] is removed, you lose the [Unresponsive] condition.

docs.title: Vision Impairment
docs.text:
Cause: When you have difficulty seeing due to a condition or injury, you have [Vision Impairment].

Effect: Tricks with the [Visual] keyword have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When the condition that caused [Vision Impairment] is removed, you lose the [Vision Impairment] condition. If you gained [Vision Impairment] as the result of an injury, receiving Surgery or Cybernetic Installation, as described in the Recovery entry of the injury description. causes you to lose [Vision Impairment]. In rare cases, this condition is permanent. If no other removal is specified, you lose [Vision Impairment] at the start of your next turn.

docs.title: Windy
docs.text:
Cause: When strong gusts of wind interfere with , it is [Windy].

Effect: When it is [Windy] and you use a Firearms trick to [Attack] a target that is [Far] away (or beyond [Far] if using a [Scope]), raise the DL by one. Also, when it is [Windy] and you use the Athletics trick, Throw, raise the DL by one.

Removal: When the wind dies down, it is no longer [Windy].

docs.title: Wounded
docs.text:
Cause: When you are reduced to half your maximum hit points (or less), you gain the [Wounded] condition. this condition follows and replaces [Healthy].

Effect: All skill actions have their DL raised by one.

Removal: When you have more than half your maximum hit points, you lose the [Wounded] condition. You also lose the [Wounded] condition if you advance to [Severely Wounded], [Death's Door], or [Dying].

docs.text:
*A Darkline Node is a black market augment installed in your cranium, near the brainstem. Fully encrypted, a Darkline Node gives you access to the Dark Net and adds an extra layer of security to protect you from hackers. *

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 10,000 ⌆ Darkline Node (Level 1) 3 [Wireless] 25,000 ⌆ Darkline Node (Level 2) 3 [Wireless] 60,000 ⌆ Darkline Node (Level 3) 3 [Wireless] 100,000 ⌆ Darkline Node (Level 4) 3 [Wireless]

Use a Darkline Node to wirelessly access the Dark Net. You can also use Darkline Node to convert a Data Bundle into an [Encrypted Package] with the same [Security] as the augment.

A Darkline Node monitors your other [Wireless] augments and provides an extra layer of [Security] against hackers. If a hacker gains [Admin] access to one of your [Wireless] augments, they must also gain [Admin] access to the Darkline Node before they can use Cybernetic Hack.

Darkline Node includes [Security] based on its level. Darkline Node (Level 1): Easy (8), Darkline Node (Level 2): Moderate (14), Darkline Node (Level 3): Hard (20), Darkline Node (Level 4): Severe (26).

docs.title: Datajack [Augment]
docs.text:
*Synonymous with hacking, a Datajack is a noticeable cranial implant, a 6.35mm (¼ inch) diameter data port, typically installed behind the ear or on the temple. *

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 10,000 ⌆ Datajack 1 [Physical]

A Datajack is required to use the Droptrip trick. and to interface directly with the Network Foam.

docs.title: Datavault [Augment]
docs.text:
Datavault, used almost exclusively by data couriers, is a data storage augment that puts Encrypted Packages in hidden partitions so they are not accessible to anyone, even you.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 5,000 ⌆ Datavault (Level 1) 1 - 10,000 ⌆ Datavault (Level 2) 2 - 25,000 ⌆ Datavault (Level 3) 3 - 100,000 ⌆ Datavault (Level 4) 4 -

Transferring an [Encrypted Package] into your [Datavault] relies upon another one of your augments to act as a source of the data. For example, to download an [Encrypted Package] from the Net and put it on your [Datavault], you could use your Datajack. You could also transfer an [Encrypted Package] to your [Datavault] from a cartridge in your Minidisk Port. You cannot transfer a regular Data Bundle into a Datavault; it must be converted into an [Encrypted Package] first. Augments like Datajack, Darkline Node, and Minidisk Port, are capable of performing this conversion.

Transferring an [Encrypted Package] into a Datavault requires something called a Claim Check. A Claim Check is a digital code with two parts. The party who will claim delivery of the [Encrypted Package] in question generates the code. One part is given to the courier, and the other part is retained. When the courier transfers the [Encrypted Package] into their Datavault, they use the first part of the Claim Check to initiate a process known as tornado fragging, in which the [Encrypted Package] is intentionally fragmented and strewn across a series of hidden partitions. Later, when the courier delivers the [Encrypted Package], the other party provides the second part of the Claim Check code, which the courier uses to recover the [Encrypted Package] from the Datavault. Transferring an [Encrypted Package] out of a Datavault automatically deletes any local copies.

A Datavault's tornado fragging process provides [Security] to any [Encrypted Package] stored within (in addition to the [Security] of the [Encrypted Package] itself). The [Security] of a Datavault is based on its level. Datavault (Level 1): Easy (8), Datavault (Level 2): Moderate (14), Datavault (Level 3): Hard (20), Datavault (Level 4): Severe (26).

docs.title: Dermal Armor [Augment]
docs.text:
Dermal Armor is metal plating inserted under your skin, typically over the rib cage and abdomen. This augmentation is obvious to anyone who observes you shirtless.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 20,000 ⌆ Dermal Armor 3 [Armor]

Dermal Armor counts as wearing Soft Armor all the time.

Dermal Armor is [Incompatible] with Subdermal NanoWeave.

docs.title: FNGR Razors [Augment]
docs.text:
Flick-Nick-Gouge-Retract. FNGR Razors by Ranco are implanted under the fingernails on one hand. They can be extended or retracted with a flick of the fingers.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 5,000 ⌆ FNGR Razors 1 [Aug Blade], [Mod], [One Hand]

FNGR Razors have a Base Value of 2 for its Melee Damage Array. FNGR Razors cannot be used to perform Finishing Move.

You can extend and retract FNGR Razors for free (0 AP).

FNGR Razors are [Incompatible] with VPR Blade and TGR Claws in the same arm.

FNGR Razors can be installed as a [Mod] in the Cybernetic Arm augment.

docs.title: Faceshifter [Augment]
docs.text:
When Faceshifter is installed, your natural face is scraped away, and a series of actuator-driven ceramic plates are mounted to the underlying bone. The entire assembly is overlayed with a NanoWeave mesh, a blank canvas for any new face you might desire.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 75,000 ⌆ Faceshifter (Level 1) 5 [Physical] 200,000 ⌆ Faceshifter (Level 2) 6 [Physical] 500,000 ⌆ Faceshifter (Level 3) 7 [Physical]

When you use Faceshifter, spend 1 AP as you take a moment to examine a face you can clearly see (in person, in a photo, or in a video). The augment is capable of producing different facial shapes, skin tones, scars, birthmarks, and blemishes, and it can even sprout synthetic hair to produce a mustache, beard, razor stubble, and the like. However, it cannot recreate symbols or artwork.

While you are wearing a face, you may store it as your "default" in the Faceshifter augment. You may only store one face at a time, and if you store a new face, it overwrites the previous one. You can shift to and from your default face for free (0 AP), even if it's not your turn.

An NPC who becomes [Suspicious] of you makes a [Basic] Threat roll to recognize that your face is cybernetic. The DL for this roll is based on the augment's level. Faceshifter (Level 1): [Suspicious] NPCs roll Threat vs. Moderate (14), Faceshifter (Level 2): [Suspicious] NPCs roll Threat vs. Hard (20), and Faceshifter (Level 3). [Suspicious] NPCs roll Threat vs. Severe (26).

docs.title: Glide-By-Wire Reflexes [Augment]
docs.text:
Glide-By-Wire Reflexes are attached to your spinal column and spread throughout your limbs. They interpret your movements to deliver computer-aided precision to achieve desired outcomes.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 125,000 ⌆ Glide-By-Wire Reflexes (Level 1) 5 [Aug Increase], [Mod] 300,000 ⌆ Glide-By-Wire Reflexes (Level 2) 8 [Aug Increase], [Mod] 750,000 ⌆ Glide-By-Wire Reflexes (Level 3) 12 [Aug Increase], [Mod]

The Glide-By-Wire Reflexes augment grants its level as an [Aug Increase] to your Agility score. That is, Glide-By-Wire Reflexes (Level 1) gives you an [Aug Increase] of 1 to your Agility score, Glide-By-Wire Reflexes (Level 2) gives you an [Aug Increase] of 2, and Glide-By-Wire Reflexes (Level 3) gives you an [Aug Increase] of 3.

You should update your Drive, Firearms, and Stealth skills to use your new Agility score.

Glide-By-Wire Reflexes can be installed as a [Mod] in the Cybernetic Spine augment.

docs.title: Gunwires [Augment]
docs.text:
Gunwires run from a contact pad installed in the palm of your hand, up the arm, to your brainstem. When paired with a compatible firearm, Gunwires use data from your weapon to provide aim assistance.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 20,000 ⌆ Gunwires 2 [Aug Bonus], [Mod], [One Hand], [Physical]

Gunwires allows you to get the +2 [Gear Bonus] to Firearms granted by a weapon's [Gunwire Grip].

If you have Cybernetic Eyes installed, Gunwires grant a +1 [Aug Bonus] to Firearms. This bonus is not dependent upon the weapon having a [Gunwire Grip].

Gunwires can be installed as a [Mod] in the Cybernetic Arm augment.

docs.title: KBR Fangs [Augment]
docs.text:
Kiss-Bleed-Retract. KBR Fangs by Ranco are implanted in the mouth. You may choose to have them replace your eye teeth or implant them behind your existing eye teeth, in which case they are retractable.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 3,000 ⌆ KBR Fangs 1 -

You can extend and retract KBR Fangs for free (0 AP).

When you use a Brawl trick and score a Success or Cool Success, you may choose to bite the target with your KBR Fangs for free (0 AP). A bite automatically deals 1 [Absolute Damage] and gives the target [Bleeding].

docs.title: Meat Rack [Augment]
docs.text:
Meat Rack by Ranco strengthens the muscles in your arms, legs, neck, back, and abdomen, providing you with an overall increase in physicality.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 80,000 ⌆ Meat Rack (Level 1) 6 [Aug Increase] 200,000 ⌆ Meat Rack (Level 2) 7 [Aug Increase] 500,000 ⌆ Meat Rack (Level 3) 9 [Aug Increase]

Meat Rack grants its level as an [Aug Increase] to your Strength score. That is, Meat Rack (Level 1) gives you an [Aug Increase] of 1 to your Strength score, Meat Rack (Level 2) gives you an [Aug Increase] of 2, and Meat Rack (Level 3) gives you an [Aug Increase] of 3.

Recalculate your Hit Points and Health Conditions using your increased Strength score and make the necessary adjustments to your character sheet. You should also update your Athletics, Brawl, and Melee skills to use your new Strength score.

docs.title: Minidisk Port [Augment]
docs.text:
A Minidisk Port, widely considered a mark of espionage, can be installed discretely anywhere on the body. This augment allows you to transfer data to and from an ejectable cartridge inserted into the port.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 5,000 ⌆ Minidisk Port (Level 1) 1 [One Hand], [Physical] 10,000 ⌆ Minidisk Port (Level 2) 1 [One Hand], [Physical] 25,000 ⌆ Minidisk Port (Level 3) 1 [One Hand], [Physical] 100,000 ⌆ Minidisk Port (Level 4) 1 [One Hand], [Physical]

It costs 1 AP to interact with a data cartridge, such as to insert or remove it from Minidisk Port, and it costs 1 AP to transfer data to or from a cartridge inserted into Minidisk Port.

Minidisk Port has no extra capabilities on its own, and it is designed to use the other augments you have installed that can act as sources of data. For example, the Comms. Cybernetic Eyes and Datajack augments could each serve as a source of data to be transferred to a cartridge with Minidisk Port.

By default, data transferred onto a cartridge using Minidisk Port is converted into an [Encrypted Package] and is readable only by you. When you convert a Data Bundle into an [Encrypted Package], you must assign a password or create a unique trigger, as described in [Encrypted Package]. The [Security] used to encode the [Encrypted Package] is based on the Minidisk Port level. Minidisk Port (Level 1): Easy (8), Minidisk Port (Level 2): Moderate (14), Minidisk Port (Level 3): Hard (20), Minidisk Port (Level 4): Severe (26).

Marketing: *In a wireless world fraught with danger, Minidisk puts the panic button in your hand. Eject. *

docs.text:
Multitool is installed in one of your fingers. With a gesture, an array of small tools protrude from underneath the fingernail.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 10,000 ⌆ Multitool 1 [Mod], [One Hand], [Physical]

When you use the [Disable Device] trick, lower the DL by one. You can deploy and stow Multitool for free (0 AP).

Multitool can be installed as a [Mod] in the Cybernetic Arm, Cybernetic Hand, and Cybernetic Digit augments.

docs.title: Neuromatrix [Augment]
docs.text:
The Neuromatrix augment, implanted in the brain, stimulates the prefrontal cortex and boosts neurotransmitters, improving cognitive focus and executive function.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 100,000 ⌆ Neuromatrix (Level 1) 4 [Aug Increase] 400,000 ⌆ Neuromatrix (Level 2) 6 [Aug Increase] 800,000 ⌆ Neuromatrix (Level 3) 8 [Aug Increase]

Neuromatrix grants its level as an [Aug Increase] to your Intelligence score. That is, Neuromatrix (Level 1) gives you an [Aug Increase] of 1 to your Intelligence score, Neuromatrix (Level 2) gives you an [Aug Increase] of 2, and Neuromatrix (Level 3) gives you an [Aug Increase] of 3.

You should update your Hacking, Culture, and Medicine skills to use your new Intelligence score.

docs.title: Pain Dial [Augment]
docs.text:
The Pain Dial is a literal, physical knob on your waistline, set atop one of your pelvic bones. Turn the dial higher to ignore greater levels of pain.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 800,000 ⌆ Pain Dial 8 [One Hand], [Physical]

Pain Dial has four positions: Off, 1, 2, and 3. Spend 1 AP to turn Pain Dial up or down by one position. For example, if Pain Dial is set to Off, spend 1 AP to turn Pain Dial to 1, spend another AP to turn Pain Dial to 2, and so on. The effects of each position is shown below.

Position Effect Off - 1 You ignore the effects of being [Wounded]. 2 You ignore the effects of being [Severely Wounded]. 3 You ignore the effects of being at [Death's Door] except you still roll for injury. If you gain [Agony], you ignore its effects.

At the start of your turn, if Pain Dial is active, make a [Basic] Resilience roll with a DL based on its current position: Easy (8) for Position 1, Moderate (14) for Position 2, and Hard (20) for Position 3. Failure means you suffer a pain overload, causing Pain Dial to shut down. You are immediately affected by any effects you were ignoring.

docs.title: PheroSynth [Augment]
docs.text:
The PheroSynth is a small, biomechanical device implanted amongst your existing organs. Connected to the body's secretion zones, it synthesizes pheromones that affect the mood and emotion of anyone who gets close to you.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 80,000 ⌆ PheroSynth 4 [Range]

When you use a [Social] trick on targets who are [Close], lower the DL by one.

docs.title: Poison Reservoir [Augment]
docs.text:
Poison Reservoir is implanted in your lower lip, at the base of your gums. Using a bio-mechanical process, it naturally produces poison which can render an unsuspecting victim unconscious.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 20,000 ⌆ Poison Reservoir 2 [Mod], [Physical]

Spend 1 AP to use Poison Reservoir to secrete poison onto your lips. The next person you kiss (skin contact is required) or with whom you share a drink must make a [Basic] Resilience or Threat roll with a DL of Moderate (14). Failure means they gain the [Drugged] condition.

Poison Reservoir naturally generates enough poison to be used once per scene.

You are immune to the poison produced by your Poison Reservoir.

Poison Reservoir can be installed as a [Mod] in the Cybernetic Lips augment.

docs.title: SLAP Gun [Augment]
docs.text:
The SLAP (Spring-Loaded Auto-Pistol) Gun by Ranco is a hidden firearm compartment. With a gesture, a hatch in your forearm pops open, and a Ripper AP9 light pistol springs out and pushes into your open hand, ready to fire.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 20,000 ⌆ SLAP Gun 2 [Concealable], [Mod]

Activating SLAP Gun is free (0 AP). Activation causes you to equip the [Light Pistol] hidden in your arm, and you may immediately use Single Shot or Burst Fire at no additional AP cost. Stowing the weapon in its compartment costs 1 AP.

SLAP Gun comes preloaded with a Ranco Ripper AP9, but any [Light Pistol] (which may contain its own mods) can be mounted in its compartment. It costs 1 AP to mount or unmount a [Light Pistol], a task which can be performed anywhere and without the need for special tools.

SLAP Gun can be installed as a [Mod] in the Cybernetic Arm augment.

docs.title: Skillset [Augment]
docs.text:
Skillset firmly attaches to your spinal column and maps directly to your brain, so that when you download a new skill, the knowledge and ability can be directly infused into your body and mind.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 600,000 ⌆ Skillset (Level 1) 6 [Mod], [Wireless] 1,000,000 ⌆ Skillset (Level 2) 10 [Mod], [Wireless] 1,400,000 ⌆ Skillset (Level 3) 14 [Mod], [Wireless]

Spend 1 AP to activate Skillset and name the Skill you want to download. You gain an [Aug Bonus] for the downloaded skill equal to the level of Skillset. Skillset (Level 1) grants a +1 [Aug Bonus]. Skillset (Level 2) grants a +2 [Aug Bonus]. Skillset (Level 3) grants a +3 [Aug Bonus].

Once downloaded, a skill and its [Aug Bonus] remain available until you download another one (which replaces the first). A [Skillset] can only hold one skill at a time. This augment does not grant access to a skill's Signature Tricks.

Skillset wirelessly downloads Skill Paks from a licensed, megacorp Skills Management Service (SMS). If you have a Darkline Node installed, you can download skills from a pirate SMS, such as one set up by a medium for their ghosts.

Skillset can be installed as a [Mod] in the Cybernetic Spine augment.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 20,000 ⌆ Speed Boost 4 -

Speed Boost makes you [Fast].

Popularized by street hackers, the Spider Fingers augment replaces all five fingers on both hands. When you use a Cyber Rig, your fingers split open to reveal an array of long, thin, articulated metal digits that let you tap its keys with blistering speed.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 40,000 ⌆ Spider Fingers 2 [Mod], [Physical], [Two Hands]

When you make a Hacking roll using your [Cyber Rig], lower the DL by one.

Spider Fingers can be installed as a [Mod] in the Cybernetic Arm or Cybernetic Hand augments.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 30,000 ⌆ Subdermal Nanoweave 3 [Armor]

You can extend and retract TGR Claws for free (0 AP).

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 70,000 ⌆ VPR Blade 7 [Aug Blade], [Mod]

You can extend and retract VPR Blade for free (0 AP).

VPR Blade is [Incompatible] with FNGR Razors and TGR Claws in the same arm.

VPR Blade can be installed as a [Mod] in the Cybernetic Arm augment.

docs.title: Voice Box [Augment]
docs.text:
The Voice Box augment is implanted within your larynx. It allows you to change your voice and make other sound effects.

Cost Augment Mesh Cost Keywords 40,000 ⌆ Voice Box 1 [Mod]

Spend 1 AP to use Voice Box to change your voice. You can replicate a specific voice with perfect accuracy, but first you need to spend 1 AP to listen to it, either live or as a recording. You can also mask your voice or apply effects to it, such as to make yourself sound raspy, garbled, robotic, etc. Last, you can use Voice Box to produce other, standard sound effects, such as the sound of a gunshot, laughter, a car alarm, and so on. The sound effects library included with Voice Box can be used to produce any reasonably common sound (GM discretion).

Voice Box can be installed as a [Mod] in the Cybernetic Larynx augment.

docs.title: Game Master
docs.text:
This is where you learn how to play the game.

When to Roll

docs.title: Calculating Threat
docs.text:
An NPC's [Threat] can be derived from their [Wits] and [Fort]. For each [Difficulty Level], the GM chooses a Regular Bonus or a Strong Bonus from those listed in the table below.

Difficulty Level Regular Bonus Strong Bonus Easy (8) +1 +2 Moderate (14) +3 +4 Hard (20) +5 +6 Severe (26) +7 +8 Extreme (32) +9 +10

The GM should use the Regular Bonus for most NPCs. The Strong Bonus is reserved for versions of the NPC who are the best of the bunch.

For example, a regular Patrol Cop has a [Wits] of Moderate (14) and a [Fort] of Moderate (14). Using the Regular Bonus for each yields +3 and +3, for a calculated [Threat] of +6. If the GM wants this NPC to be a very competent Patrol Cop, they can take the Strong Bonus instead, which would yield +4 and +4, for a [Threat] of +8.

docs.title: NPCs
docs.text: Non-Player Characters, or NPCs, are managed by the GM. They are contacts, enemies, and everyday people you might see on the street.

docs.title: NPC Traits
docs.text: NPCs have three traits: [Wits], [Fort], and [Threat].

docs.title: Wits and Fort
docs.text:
[Wits] represent the NPC's intelligence, awareness, and critical thinking. When a player uses a trick to manipulate or deceive an NPC, they roll against the NPC's [Wits].

[Fort], short for Fortitude, represents the NPC's willpower, grit, and determination. When a player uses a trick to intimidate an NPC, they roll against the NPC's [Fort].

[Wits] and [Fort] are each expressed as a [Difficulty Level] based on how hard or easy it is to manipulate or intimidate the NPC. For example, a snooty maître d' who notices everything but who is also a coward might have a [Wits] of Hard (20) and a [Fort] of Easy (8).

docs.title: Threat
docs.text:
[Threat] represents an NPC's overall competence and the danger they pose to the player characters. As its name implies, the more capable the NPC, the higher their [Threat].

[Threat] is expressed as a bonus of between +1 and +20. When the GM rolls for the NPC, they add [Threat] to get the result. [Threat] is used for all NPC rolls.

The GM can assign a [Threat] based on the table below, or they use the rules for Calculating Threat to derive a bonus from the NPC's [Wits] and [Fort].

NPC Tier Threat Range Examples Typical +1 to +6 Street Vendor, Patrol Cop, Gang Member Professional +7 to +12 Forever Wars Veteran, Megacorp Security, Yakuza Bodyguard Elite +13 to +17 Megacorp Elite Guard, Chromed Yakuza Assassin Ultra +18 to +20 Megacorp Ultra Elite Guard, Unstoppable Killer Robot. docs.title: NPC Hit Points
docs.text: NPCs have hit points equal to their [Threat] x 5. For example, an NPC with a [Threat] of +1 has 10 HP, a [Threat] of +7 yields 35 HP, and a [Threat] of +13 gives the NPC 65 HP.

docs.title: NPC Health Levels
docs.text:
An NPC has four health levels, as described below.

NPC Health Level NPC Hit Points Penalty Description Uninjured Max HP None NPC has full hit points. No penalties. Hurt At or Below 50% HP DLs Raised by one NPC has half (or less) of their hit points remaining. DLs are raised by one. Defeated At or Below 10% HP Cannot Make Rolls NPC has 10% (or less) of their hit points remaining. NPC is dead or nearly so. They cannot make rolls, though they may be able to take actions like crawling or speaking, at the GM's discretion.

docs.title: NPC Health Array
docs.text: To make it easier to track NPC health, the GM can use an NPC Health Array, which looks like this (for an NPC with a [Threat] of +13): 65/33/7. This represents the NPC's max hit points, the level at which they are [Hurt] and have their DLs raised by one, and the point at which they ae [Defeated], respectively.

docs.title: NPC Skills and Tricks
docs.text: NPCs don't have skills (or skill bonuses) like player characters do. They use [Threat] instead.. However, NPCs do use tricks. Just like a player, an NPC can make a roll using any of the core tricks presented in these rules. If the NPC knows a signature trick, it should be listed in their stat block.

docs.title: NPC Gear
docs.text: NPCs have access to gear, including armor and weapons. An NPC's gear should be listed in their stat block.

docs.title: NPC Augments
docs.text: NPCs often have augments, which the GM is encouraged to describe (assuming the augments are visible), but they do not alter the NPC's traits. An NPC who has a [Threat] of +7 does not "get stronger" and see an increase to +8 if the GM describes them as having muscle replacements. Augments that provide other types of functionality, including those which modify the DL of a roll, can be used by NPCs as normal and should be noted in their stat block.

docs.title: Tiers of Play
docs.text:
There are three tiers of play in this game, as shown in the table below. This table is meant to help the GM understand how effective a character's bonus will be in overcoming a given [Difficulty Level]. Savvy players will find ways to lower the DL, which can allow them to punch above their weight, so to speak.

Character Tier Bonus Range Their "Standard" Challenge Their "Hard" Challenge Rookie +1 to +6 Moderate (14) Hard (20) Expert +7 to +12 Hard (20) Severe (26) Veteran +13 to +17 Severe (26) Extreme (32)

For example, a character with a bonus of +5 (including ability score, gear bonus, and aug bonus) is considered a Rookie. When making rolls with that bonus, the player will regularly overcome a [Difficulty Level] of Moderate (14), but their results against a Hard (20) will be hit and miss. A [Difficulty Level] of Severe (26) or higher will be nigh impossible, unless the crew has a way to lower the DL.

As characters gain XP, upgrade their gear, and install new augments, their bonuses can be increased. As a character progresses into the Expert and Veteran tiers, they will be capable of handling higher DLs.

docs.text:
Lifestyle Cost per Month Security Elite Lifestyle 1,000,000 ⌆ Extreme (32)

You have it all, a multi-level penthouse, multiple vacation homes, a private island, a full-time staff of at least a dozen people, a private jet, helicopters, and cars. You eat only the best food. In a city of wall-to-wall concrete and steel, your properties are decorated with trees and plants, coy ponds and endangered animals. In Ridgeworld, you live at the peak, the pinnacle of the city, the very top of what was once known as the Appalachian Mountains.

docs.title: High [Lifestyle]
docs.text:
Lifestyle Cost per Month Security High Lifestyle 10,000 ⌆ Hard (20)

You have a well-appointment apartment with two bedrooms, a full kitchen, a private bathroom, high-end entertainment, and perhaps most importantly, a view. Your neighbors are polite if curt, and crime is virtually nonexistent. You are accustomed to eating quality food, real vegetables, fruits, and proteins, chicken, pork, and beef, even if they were technically grown in a lab. In Ridgeworld, your apartment is situated near the top, on the upper region of the ridge.

docs.title: Low [Lifestyle]
docs.text:
Lifestyle Cost per Month Security Low Lifestyle 1,000 ⌆ Easy (8)

You pay for a box flat, a single occupancy room the size of a coat closet (both horizontal and vertical configurations are available). A box flat includes a cred-operated faucet, a floor drain, a vid-screen, and a bed. Cooking and open flame are strictly prohibited. Communal, cred-op showers are available, though not always operational. In Ridgeworld, you live in one of hundreds of box flat residential towers built along the lower ridge.

docs.title: Luxury [Lifestyle]
docs.text:
Lifestyle Cost per Month Security Luxury Lifestyle 100,000 ⌆ Severe (26)

You have a spacious, luxury apartment with multiple bedrooms, multiple bathrooms, a kitchen worthy of a top chef, and top-of-the-line entertainment options. You even have enough room for a live-in steward or au pair. With massive, wall-to-ceiling windows, you regularly enjoy a spectacular view. In Ridgeworld, you are at the top of the ridge, so far up that you can barely even see those who live below you.

docs.title: Middle [Lifestyle]
docs.text:
Lifestyle Cost per Month Security Middle Lifestyle 5,000 ⌆ Moderate (14)

You rent a small, one-room apartment, which includes a cred-op faucet/toilet combo unit with sink, and a small kitchen area equipped to heat up prefab foodstuffs. Apartment buildings offer cred-op private showers on each floor, which are shared amongst the residents. In Ridgeworld, you live in the middle of the city, not at the top, but not at the bottom either. Your apartment building might be grungy, but crime is manageable and many neighborhoods have a bustling economy and active night life.

docs.title: Parking Space [Lifestyle]
docs.text:

You pay for a parking space in a massive, concrete car park.

docs.title: Street [Lifestyle]

You have no home. You live by scavenging and begging for food. You sleep where you can find shelter. You live on the street long enough, and you learn which spots are better than others. In Ridgeworld, you live among the dregs in the lowest part of the city, down near the pumps that constantly run to keep the tidewaters away.

docs.title: Lifestyles Overview
docs.text:
In this game, your character has a monthly bill you have to pay called a Lifestyle. You can choose to pay for whichever lifestyle you want, and you can pay for up to three months in advance (if you are suddenly flush with cred, for example). However, if you the start of the month comes and you do not have the creds to pay for your current lifestyle, you will be forced to move down to a lifestyle that you are willing and able to pay for.

docs.title: Damage Array
docs.text:
All weapons (including unarmed attacks) express damage as a [Damage Array].

A [Damage Array] holds three values separated by slashes, like this: 5/10/25. These values correspond to the damage dealt on a Fade, Success, and Cool Success, respectively. The first number is [Minimum Damage]. The second is [Normal Damage], and the last is [Maximum Damage]. Refer to Outcomes for more information on Fade, Success, and Cool Success.

For example, you draw your Ranco .357 Equalizer and use Single Shot (a Firearms trick) to shoot at the security guard. You make a roll and score a Fade. According to the outcomes for Single Shot, a Fade deals [Minimum Damage]. The [Damage Array] for your Equalizer is 9/18/45. Since the first number in the array is 9, you deal 9 points of damage to the guard.

docs.title: Firearms Damage
docs.text:
Each of a weapon's firing modes has its own [Damage Array]. There are three firing modes and corresponding Firearms tricks: Single Shot, Burst Fire, and Full Auto. Some weapons are capable of performing only in one or two of these modes; others can use all three.

When developing new firearms for use in the game, the GM should use the formula shown in the chart below.

Minimum Damage Normal Damage Maximum Damage Base Value Base Value x 2 Base Value x 5

Each firing mode a weapon can use has its own Base Value.

For example, the Graham M21-S has a Base Value of 4 for Single Shot, so its Single Shot [Damage Array] is 4/8/20. It has a Base Value of 9 for Burst Fire, so that [Damage Array] is 9/18/45. The M21-S is not capable of Full Auto, so that [Damage Array] is left blank.

docs.title: Brawl Damage
docs.text:
Damage dealt by the Brawl skill is based on your Strength score. Calculate your character's Brawl [Damage Array] using the formula below.

Minimum Damage Normal Damage Maximum Damage Strength Strength x 2 Strength x 5

For example, a character with a Strength score of 3 would have an Unarmed Strike [Damage Array] of 3/6/15.

docs.title: Melee Damage
docs.text:
Melee weapons, like knives and clubs, have their own Base Value which is added to the character's Strength score when calculating its [Damage Array], as shown below.

Minimum Damage Normal Damage Maximum Damage Strength + Base Value (Strength + Base Value) x 2 (Strength + Base Value) x 5

For example, a character with a Strength score of 3 is wielding a knife with a Base Value of 1. So, [Minimum Damage] is 4, [Normal Damage] is 8, and [Maximum Damage] is 20. The Melee Strike [Damage Array] for this weapon when used by this character is 4/8/20.
