docs.text:
This is where you learn how to play the game.

When to Roll

docs.title: Health Condition Effects
docs.text:
You can only have one health condition at a time, and your health condition changes when your hit points drop below (or rise above) the one you currently have.

For example, a character that has max hit points (30 hp) gets shot in the back. They take 10 points of damage. This reduces their hit points to from 30 hp to 20 hp. Their current hit points are still in the [Healthy] range because the next level down, [Wounded], starts at 15 hp. If this character gets shot again and takes another 10 points of damage, they will go from 20 hp to 10 hp, and that will drop them down from being [Healthy] to being [Wounded].

Health Condition Hit Points Example Effect Healthy Max Hit Points 30 hp You are healthy. Wounded Half of Healthy 15 hp Tricks with the [Physical] trait have their DL raised by one. Severely Wounded Half of Wounded 8 hp You can only [Move] once per turn. Skill actions with the [Physical] keyword have their DL raised by one. Death's Door Half of Severely Wounded 4 hp You are [Prone] and can only move by crawling once per turn. All skill actions have their DL raised by one. The first time you gain [Death's Door] during a scene, refer to Sustaining an Injury. Dying 0 Hit Points 0 hp You are [Unconscious]. You gain Dying 1. At the start of your turn, make a [Basic] Resilience roll with a Moderate (14) DL. Success means you gain the [Stabilized] condition. Failure means Dying increases by 1. When your Dying value is greater than your Resilience score, you are dead.

docs.title: Hit Points and Conditions
docs.text:
Your character's health is measured in hit points (hp) and is based on your Strength and Resilience scores.

All characters have a maximum number of hit points equal to (Strength + Resilience) x 5.

For example, a character with Strength 2 and Resilience 4 would have:

Step Example Hit Point Calculation 1 (2 + 4) x 5 = Maximum hit points 2 (6) x 5 = 30 3 30 hp Max

docs.title: Calculating Health Conditions
docs.text:
Calculate your health conditions as shown below. When dividing a score in half results in a fraction, round up.

Health Condition Hit Points Example with 30 hp Max Healthy Max Hit Points 30 hp Wounded Half of Healthy 15 hp Severely Wounded Half of Wounded 8 hp Death's Door Half of Severely Wounded 4 hp

docs.title: Stabilization DL
docs.text:
When your character is [Dying] or suffering from one of several other conditions, they need to be [Stabilized] by someone who can make a Medicine (First Aid) roll. Your [Stabilization DL] is the Difficulty Level used for those rolls.

Your [Stabilization DL] is based on your Resilience score, as shown below.

Resilience Score Stabilization DL 1 Extreme (32) 2 Severe (26) 3 Hard (20) 4 Moderate (14) 5 Easy (8)

docs.title: Sustaining an Injury
docs.text: In this game, combat is dangerous, and its effects can be brutal. If you take enough damage, it can result in an injury, an enduring effect which might be easily resolved, could require surgery, or may even lead to cybernetic replacement.

docs.title: Injury Roll
docs.text: The first time you drop to Death's Door in a scene, make an Injury Roll. Roll 2d10 and consult the Injury Level Chart below to determine if you sustain an injury. No matter how many times you drop to Death's Door in a single scene, you only make an Injury Roll once.

docs.title: Roll with +2
docs.text: Some extra dangerous attacks available to the GM indicate that if the attack drops a character to Death's Door and triggers an Injury roll, the roll should be made with a +2. This +2 modifier applies to your roll on the Injury Level Chart and your subsequent roll on the specific Injury Chart (Minor, Significant, Terrible, Grievous, or Massive).

docs.title: Injury Level Chart
docs.text:
Make your Injury Roll and consult the Injury Level Chart below to determine your character's injury.

Roll 2d10 Injury Level Effect 2-3 None You do not sustain an injury. You gain [Lucky]. 4-5 Minor Injury You are [Traumatized]. Roll on the Minor Injury Chart. 6-8 Significant Injury You are [Traumatized]. Roll on the Significant Injury Chart. 9-12 Terrible Injury You are [Traumatized]. Roll on the Terrible Injury Chart. 13-16 Grievous Injury You are [Traumatized]. Roll on the Grievous Injury Chart. 17-20 Massive Injury You are [Traumatized]. Roll on the Massive Injury Chart.

docs.title: Resist the Injury
docs.text:
If your Injury Roll was 4 or higher, it means you suffered an injury. However, your Resilience allows you to resist the injury.

Make a [Basic] Resilience roll with a Hard (20) DL. If you succeed, lower the Injury Level by one. If this reduces the Injury Level to None, then you do not sustain an injury.

For example, if you get an 11 on your Injury Roll, it means you have to roll on the Terrible Injury Chart. However, if you succeed on your [Basic] Resilience roll, the Injury Level is lowered by one from Terrible Injury to Significant Injury.

docs.title: Specific Injury
docs.text:
If, after making a [Basic] Resilience roll, you still sustain an injury, roll on the appropriate chart below to determine your specific injury. If you applied a +2 modifier when you rolled on the Injury Level Chart, you also apply a +2 modifier to this roll.

The charts below include a description of the injury, its mechanical effect, and the steps necessary for recovery. Medical science in the world of the GHOSTBURN has made such astounding advances that even the most critical of injuries can be treated so effectively that patients are fully recovered in a week's time.

docs.title: Qualifies for Field Surgery
docs.text: Some injuries can be treated in the field, while others require the patient to be moved to a suitable [Location], such as a hospital. Refer to the description of [Surgery] for more information.

docs.title: Keywords
docs.text:
This is where you learn how to play the game.

When to Roll

docs.title: Absolute Damage
docs.text: [Absolute Damage] is 1 damage. This is the absolute lowest amount of damage any [Attack] can deal where the roll yielded a Fade, Success, or Cool Success.

docs.title: Admin
docs.text: You have [Admin] access to a device or system. You can perform all the same functions as an [Operator], but you also have full control and can make changes, such as performing a shutdown, locking out users, granting access to anyone you like, disabling alerts, modifying configurations, and so on.

docs.title: Advanced Supplies
docs.text: A high-quality version of [Supplies] worth 1,000 cred (which are consumed upon use)

docs.title: Armor
docs.text:
If you're wearing armor when you take damage from an [Attack], the damage is [Reduced]. If your armor is rated against the [Weapon Group] used to make the [Attack], the damage is [Reduced] again.

Armor Type Rated Against Weapon Groups Leather Jacket [Blades] Reinforced Leather [Blades], [Blunt Force] Soft Armor [Small Arms] NanoWeave Armor [Blades], [Small Arms] Hard Armor [Blades], [Blunt Force], [Small Arms], [Rifles]

For example, say your character is wearing Soft Armor, which is rated against [Small Arms].

You are hit by an EZTech Punisher Lite (which is belongs to the [Small Arms] weapon group) for [Normal Damage] of 10, Since you are wearing armor, the damage is [Reduced] to [Minimum Damage] of 5. Since your armor is rated against [Small Arms], the damage is [Reduced] again to [Absolute Damage] of 1.

On the other hand, when you are hit by a Graham PX-90 Carbine (Rifle) for [Normal Damage] of 18, the damage is [Reduced] to its [Minimum Damage] of 9. Since your armor is not rated against Rifles, the damage is not [Reduced] any further.

docs.title: Attack
docs.text: An offensive action taken against an opponent usually with the intent to harm.

docs.title: Attitude
docs.text: [Attitude] is an NPC trait. It represents how an NPC feels about a particular person. [Attitude] can be thought of as a spectrum with three values: [Friendly], [Neutral], and [Hostile]. Some tricks cause a target's [Attitude] to go improve or worsen.

docs.title: Auditory
docs.text: You must be able to hear to use this trick.

docs.title: Aug Blade
docs.text:
[Aug Blade] is a [Weapon Type]. It belongs to the [Bladed] weapon group. The [Aug Blade] weapon type includes the following keywords: [Brawl], [Melee], [One Hand], and [Physical].

Weapons with this [Weapon Type] use the Brawl skill to [Attack], but they use the Melee Damage Array and can only use tricks from the Melee skill.

For example, the TGR Claws augment is classified as an [Aug Blade]. To make an [Attack], you would Make a Roll using Brawl, but you would not use the Unarmed Strike trick. Instead, you would choose from the tricks found in the Melee skill, such as Melee Strike, Dazzling Strike, or Leaping Strike.

docs.title: Aug Bonus
docs.text:
Your cybernetic augments or psionic mutations can grant aug bonuses to specific skills (up to +3).

Multiple aug bonuses do not stack, and only the highest gear bonus is applied. For example, if you have have a piece of cybernetics that gives a +1 aug bonus to Persuade and another that gives a +2 aug bonus to Persuade, only the +2 aug bonus applies to your Persuade rolls.

docs.title: Aug Increase
docs.text:
Some cybernetic augmentations permanently improve ability scores. This is known as an [Aug Increase]. Unlike bonuses, when you get an [Aug Increase] to the same ability score from two or more sources, you combine them, up to a maximum [Aug Increase] of +3. Write the [Aug Increase] on your character sheet and writ the adjusted ability score in parenthesis behind the natural ability score.

For example, a character with an Intelligence score of 3 gets a Neuromatrix (Level 2) installed. This grants the character an [Aug Increase] of 2 to their Intelligence score. The player notes the [Aug Increase] of 2 on their character sheet. For their Intelligence score, they write it like this: 3 (5). This indicates the character has a natural Intelligence score of 3 but it has been increased to 5 through cybernetic augmentation.

docs.title: Bad Memory
docs.text: Some tricks give you a [Bad Memory] when you roll a Fade or Glitch. As long as you hold onto that [Bad Memory], you are [Preoccupied]. To get rid of the [Bad Memory], you must describe it (make it up) and share it with the group on your turn. Your [Bad Memory] will ideally be related to your Background, Burn, or Hook. You are not required to share the [Bad Memory] in character, and you are free to solicit ideas and help from the GM or the other players. The idea is that [Bad Memory] offers an opportunity to share a moment from your character's backstory. Players and GMs should refrain from straying into topics or themes that other players may find uncomfortable.

docs.title: Basic
docs.text: When the rules call for you to make a [Basic] roll, they indicate the skill or ability score to use and the Difficulty Level for the roll. They also describe the consequence for getting a Success or Failure. Unlike most rolls in the game, a [Basic] roll has only two outcomes (Success and Failure), and the text only describes one of those two outcomes (because it is the only outcome that has a consequence attached).

docs.title: Blades
docs.text: The [Blades] weapon group contains the following [Weapon Types]: [Aug Blade], [Long Blade] and [Short Blade].

docs.title: Blunt
docs.text: [Blunt] is a [Weapon Type]. It belongs to the [Blunt Force] weapon group. The [Blunt] weapon type includes the following keywords: [Melee].

docs.title: Blunt Force
docs.text: The [Blunt Force] weapon group contains the following Weapon Types: Club and Unarmed.

docs.title: Brawl
docs.text: An [Attack] made using body as a weapon, such as with your hands, against an opponent who is [Close] to you.

docs.title: Close
docs.text: Represents a very short distance between you and the target. For example, the target is [Close] if you are in the same room (like a living room or private office), if it would take only a few steps to reach them, or if you could reach out and touch them.

docs.title: Combat Opportunity
docs.text: When you gain a [Combat Opportunity], you may immediately [Move] or [Attack] for free (0 AP), even if it's not your turn.

docs.title: Concealable
docs.text: A [Concealable] weapon or item is easily hidden on your person and can only be discovered with a Search roll.

docs.title: Concentrate
docs.text: You must be able to focus to use this trick. Persistent loud noises, unpleasant smells, personal illness, and other odious effects raise the DL by one. If it is impossible to [Concentrate], the skill or trick cannot be used.

docs.title: Condition
docs.text: A [Condition] is a status that can be applied to characters. Each condition includes its primary cause and often suggests other possible causes, describes the effect the condition has on a person, and explains how the condition is removed.

docs.title: Contact
docs.text: A [Contact] is a person you know and who has a Friendly [Attitude] towards you. A [Contact] is someone who will help you (not necessarily for free) when you call upon them. A [Contact] is a permanent part of your character and they remain available to you as a resource from one mission to the next. You can call upon any given [Contact] no more than once per session.

docs.title: Control Deck
docs.text:
A piece of hardware used to control drones and vehicles.

To connect a [Control Deck] to a [Drone] or [Vehicle] so you can control it, you must have [Admin] access to it. You automatically have this access on any drone or vehicle you own.

You may use a [Control Deck] to remotely control a [Drone] or [Vehicle] over [Wireless]. This requires you to either wear a connected [Control Helmet] (included when you buy a [Control Deck]) or connect using the Control Port augment.

Some vehicles have a [Control Deck] integrated into their onboard controls. Such a [Vehicle] allows you to [Strap In] if you have the [Control Port] augment.

docs.title: Control Helmet
docs.text: A helmet designed for use with a [Control Deck], often stylized with an opaque visor. A [Control Helmet] is [Incompatible] with the Control Port augment. That is, if you have a [Control Port] augment, you have no need for a [Control Helmet].

docs.title: Core Trick
docs.text: Each skill has one or more core tricks. For example, First Aid is a core trick of the Medicine skill. A core trick includes its own outcomes chart that tells you exactly how to interpret the results. This is done to provide a consistent and efficient play experience for common in-game situations, such as needing to to stabilize a friend who has just suffered a grievous injury in combat. You may use any core trick, even if you have no skill bonus in the associated skill. For example, if you have no skill bonus for Firearms, you can still use the Single Shot trick by rolling Agility.

docs.title: Counterattack
docs.text: A special kind of [Reaction] triggered by some tricks and allows you to immediately use a trick to [Attack] the opponent that triggered it, even if it's not your turn.

docs.title: Crashes
docs.text: When a [Vehicle] or [Drone] [Crashes], it collides with an immovable object or hazard and comes to a sudden stop. If the [Vehicle] or [Drone] was traveling at [High Speed], it is totaled. If the driver was wearing a safety belt, they take 5 damage. Otherwise, they take 50 points of damage. At [Moderate Speed], a [Vehicle] takes 30 damage and a [Drone] takes 15 damage. A [Vehicle] driver takes 3 damage with a safety belt or 30 damage without it. At [Low Speed], the [Vehicle] or [Drone] takes 10 damage or 5 damage, respectively. A driver takes 1 damage with a safety belt or 10 damage without it.

docs.title: Cyber Rig
docs.text: A portable device with a keyboard, [Datajack], and an AR Display. A [Cyber Rig] is required to use Hacking tricks.

docs.title: Damage Array
docs.text: Damage for a weapon or an unarmed brawl attack is expressed as a [Damage Array], which is a set of three numbers, separated by slashes, such as 5/10/25. These are the [Minimum Damage](/../[Keywords/Keyword_Minimum_Damage)], [Normal Damage], and [Maximum Damage](/../[Keywords/Keyword_Maximum_Damage)] values, respectively.

docs.title: Datajack
docs.text: A cybernetic implant used to directly interface with devices and systems, such as a [Cyber Rig] or [Drone]. When you are jacked in, you gain the [Unaware] condition.

docs.title: Disabled
docs.text: When a device, system feature, or cybernetic implant is [Disabled], it ceases to perform its function(s). A maglock no longer locks, a video camera no longer streams video, a cyberarm no longer moves, and so on.

docs.title: Downgraded
docs.text: When an outcome is [Downgraded], it moves down one level on the PtG_Outcomes chart. That is, a Cool Success becomes a Success, a Success becomes a Fade, and a Fade becomes a Glitch. A Glitch cannot be [Downgraded].

docs.title: Drone
docs.text: An unmanned flying device equipped with at least one video camera. A [Drone] can be outfitted with additional cameras and microphones for reconnaissance and weapons for combat. Some drones also include a small storage area which can be used to deliver a payload, reticulating arms for remotely manipulating objects, and other features.

docs.title: Enabled
docs.text: When a device, system feature, or cybernetic implant is enabled, it is functioning.

docs.title: Encrypted Package
docs.text:
An [Encrypted Package] is a data bundle that has been protected with encryption. You cannot access the data inside an [Encrypted Package] unless you have the key. A key could be a password, but it could also be a unique trigger, which is a condition (or set of conditions) for automatically unlocking the data bundle.

For example, a DateTime Trigger unlocks an [Encrypted Package] at a specific date and time; a Visual Trigger unlocks an [Encrypted Package] when an attached video device sees a preselected image, such as a particular face or pattern; and a Location Trigger unlocks an [Encrypted Package] only when the device on which it is stored has been moved to a particular place, such as a certain address, or even to a specific floor, room, or chair at that address.

An [Encrypted Package] can be cracked by breaking the [Security] that protects it. The [Security] of an [Encrypted Package] is determined by the device that encrypted the data.

docs.title: Far
docs.text: Represents a long distance between you and the target. For example, the target is [Far] away if they are at the end of the block, on the other side of a stadium, or standing on a balcony five stories up.

docs.title: Fast
docs.text: [Fast] means that on your turn, you may [Move] one time for free (0 AP).

docs.title: Fierce Look
docs.text: While wearing a [Fierce Look] in its matching social environment (Street, City, Underworld, Milsec, or Corporate), the DL of Intimidate rolls is lowered by one. A [Fierce Look] can be created with a Wardrobe, High End.

docs.title: Fine Control
docs.text: You must be able to engage in fine motor control, (such as the type of control needed to tie your shoes or write with a pencil), to use this trick.

docs.title: Firearm
docs.text: A [Firearm] is a weapon that uses the Firearms skill. The following Weapon Types fall into this category: Heavy Pistol, Light Pistol, Shotgun. SMG, and Rifle.

docs.title: Fly
docs.text: [Fly] works just like [Move] except you can move [Far] away with 1 AP.

docs.title: Fort
docs.text: [Fort], short for Fortitude, represents the NPC's willpower, grit, and determination. When a player uses a trick to intimidate an NPC, they roll against the NPC's [Fort]. [Fort] is expressed as a [Difficulty Level].

docs.title: Friendly
docs.text:
When an NPC has an [Attitude] of [Friendly] towards you, they are helpful and kind to you. When you use a [Social] trick on a [Friendly] NPC, lower the DL by one.

If the target's [Attitude] is [Friendly], it cannot be improved. If something causes it to worsen, it drops to [Neutral].

docs.title: Gear Bonus
docs.text:
Your weapons and equipment can grant gear bonuses to specific skills (up to +3). For example, a laser sight gives a +1 gear bonus to Firearms.

Multiple gear bonuses do not stack, and only the highest gear bonus is applied. For example, if you have have a piece of gear that gives a +1 gear bonus to Firearms and another that gives a +2 gear bonus to Firearms, only the +2 gear bonus applies to your Firearms rolls.

docs.title: Gift
docs.text: A gift is an item of value. A minor gift is worth around 500 cred, a regular gift is worth around 2,000 cred, and an expensive gift is worth 5,000 cred or more.

docs.title: Group
docs.text: This trick can be used on a group of people. Raise the DL of the skill action by one for every 10 members. If the trick uses [Wits] or [Fort] as its DL, use the highest amongst the group.

docs.title: Gun
docs.text: A weapon used with the Firearms skill, including pistols, submachines, rifles, and shotguns.

docs.title: Handling
docs.text: [Handling] represents how easy or difficult a [Vehicle] s to control. [Handling] can have one of three values: Good, Average, and Poor. When a Drive trick says to apply the [Handling] of a [Vehicle], do the following: Good [Handling] lowers the DL by one level; Poor [Handling] raises the DL by one; and Average [Handling] has no effect on the DL.

docs.title: Heavy Pistol
docs.text: [Heavy Pistol] is a [Weapon Type]. It belongs to the [Heavy Arms] weapon group. The [Heavy Pistol] weapon type includes the following keywords: [Firearm], [One Hand]. [Recoil], and [Two-Handed Grip].

docs.title: High Speed
docs.text: A [Vehicle] or [Drone] traveling at 100 kph (about 60 mph) or higher. When you are moving at [High Speed] and are called upon to make a Drive roll, raise the DL by one. For each additional 100 kph, raise the DL by one again.

docs.title: Hostile
docs.text:
Hostile

When an NPC has an [Attitude] of [Hostile] towards you, they are discourteous and unkind to you, and they might even [Attack] you. When you use a [Social] trick on a [Hostile] NPC, raise the DL by one.

If an NPC's [Attitude] is [Hostile] and something causes it to improve, it moves to [Neutral]. If something causes it to worsen, the target stays at Hostile gains the [Break] condition.

docs.title: Improvised Trick
docs.text: When these rules don't cover an action a player wants their character to perform, the GM can allow the player to make a roll and declare it an improvised trick. The GM is responsible for setting the Difficulty Level and determining the outcomes. The GM should feel free to work with the players to identify the outcomes, and they should be publicly shared with everyone at the table before the player makes their roll.

docs.title: Incompatible
docs.text: Two things that cannot work together are [Incompatible]. When you encounter this keyword, it will be in reference to two things, such as two augments or a weapon and a mod. For example, [Dermal Armor] and [Subdermal Nanoweave] are [Incompatible], which means if you have one installed, you cannot install the other.

docs.title: Language
docs.text: You must be able to speak the same [Language] as the target to use this skill or trick.

docs.title: Light Pistol
docs.text: [Light Pistol] is a [Weapon Type]. It belongs to the [Light Arms] weapon group. The [Light Pistol] weapon type includes the following keywords: [Concealable], [Firearm], [One Hand], and [Two-Handed Grip].

docs.title: Location
docs.text: A specific, definable place in the world that serves some significance, such as the home of a witness, the destination of a suspicious person, or the crew's hideout.

docs.title: Long Blade
docs.text: [Long Blade] is a [Weapon Type]. It belongs to the [Bladed] weapon group. The [Long Blade] weapon type includes the following keywords: [Melee] and [Two Hands].

docs.title: Low Speed
docs.text: A [Vehicle] or [Drone] traveling at 25 kph or lower. When you are moving at [Low Speed] and are called upon to make a Drive roll, lower the DL by one.

docs.title: Luck Bonus
docs.text: After you make a roll, you can spend a [Luck Point] to get a +2 Luck Bonus to your roll result. If the roll uses one of your Favored Skills, you get a +3 Luck Bonus instead.

docs.title: Lucky
docs.text: When a Cool Success or another effect makes you [Lucky], you recover 1 Luck Point.

docs.title: Manipulator Arm
docs.text: A [Drone] can be outfitted with a [Manipulator Arm] and accompanying hand. The [Manipulator Arm] is capable of [Fine Control].

docs.title: Maximum Damage
docs.text: In a [Damage Array], the last number listed is the [Maximum Damage] value. This number is 5x the [Minimum Damage](/../[Keywords/Keyword_Minimum_Damage)] value. For example, in the [Damage Array], 5/10/25, the 25 is the [Maximum Damage] value.

docs.title: Melee
docs.text: An [Attack] made using a Melee Weapon, such as a knife, katana, or sledgehammer, against an opponent who is [Close] to you.

docs.title: Minimum Damage
docs.text: In a [Damage Array], the first number listed is the [Minimum Damage] value, also known as base damage. For example, in the [Damage Array], 5/10/25, the 5 is the [Minimum Damage] value.

docs.title: Mod
docs.text:
A [Mod] is a special feature that can be installed into a cybernetic augment. When you install a [Mod] into a cybernetic augment, you only pay the Mesh Cost of the Mod that exceeds the Mesh Cost of the cybernetic augment.

For example, TGR Claws have a Mesh Cost of 4, which must be paid when the augment is installed normally. However, if TGR Claws are installed in a Mod Slot in a Cybernetic Arm, which has a Mesh Cost of 5, you pay 0 Mesh for the TGR Claws because its Mesh Cost does not exceed the Mesh Cost of the Cybernetic Arm.

Here's another example. Glide-By-Wire Reflexes (Level 3) have a Mesh Cost of 12, which must be paid when the augment is installed normally. However, if that same augment is installed as a [Mod] in a Cybernetic Spine (Level 1), which has a Mesh Cost of 5, then you only pay 7 Mesh for it (because its Mesh Cost of 12 is 7 more than the Mesh Cost of 5 for the Cybernetic Spine in which the [Mod] is being installed).

docs.title: Mod Slots
docs.text: The entry for each [Cybernetic Augmentation] has a trait called [Mod Slots], which tells you how many mods you can install in that augment.

docs.title: Moderate Speed
docs.text: A [Vehicle] or [Drone] traveling between 25 kph and 100 kph

docs.title: Move
docs.text:
When you use [Move], you spend 1 AP to go somewhere [Nearby]. If you keep going and immediately spend another 1 AP to use [Move] again, you somewhere that was [Far] from your original position.

For example, say you are in the living room. The font yard is [Nearby]. To [Move] from the living room to the front yard costs 1 AP. If you want to keep going, you can spend 1 AP again to [Move] somewhere [Far] away, like three blocks away.

docs.title: Nearby
docs.text: Represents a short distance between you and the target. For example, the target is [Nearby] if they are sitting on the other side of the cafeteria, standing across the street. or are in another car three lanes over from you on the freeway.

docs.title: Neutral
docs.text:
Neutral

When an NPC has an [Attitude] of [Neutral] towards you, they are ambivalent towards you. They are willing to do business with you and will engage you in small talk, but they are not interested in doing you any favors.

If an NPC's [Attitude] is [Neutral] and it improves, it moves to [Friendly]. If it worsens, it moves to [Hostile].

docs.title: Normal Damage
docs.text: In a [Damage Array], the middle number listed is the [Normal Damage] value. This number is 2 times the [Minimum Damage](/../[Keywords/Keyword_Minimum_Damage)] value. For example, in the [Damage Array], 5/10/25, the 10 is the [Normal Damage] value.

docs.title: One Hand
docs.text: You must use at least one hand.

docs.title: Operator
docs.text: You have [Operator] access to a device or system. You can perform basic functions as they are designed to be used, such as seeing through a video camera or changing the text on a digital sign.

docs.title: Opposed
docs.text:
This trick uses an [Opposed] roll to determine the outcome instead of the standard resolution process.

You roll just like you normally do. The GM rolls 2d10 and adds the NPC's [Threat] bonus. Compare your result to the GM's result. If your result is 4 or more higher than the GM's roll, it's a Cool Success. If you get 1-3 higher than the GM's roll, it is a Success. If your result is equal to the GM's roll, it's a Fade. Lower than the GM's roll and it's a Glitch.

docs.title: Optimal Range
docs.text: A [Firearm] has an attribute called [Optimal Range]. A weapon's [Optimal Range] is one of the [Range] values: [Close], [Nearby], and [Far]. If you make an [Attack] against a target at a [Range] other than the [Optimal Range], raise the DL by one for each range increment the target is away from the [Optimal Range]. For example, if your weapon has an [Optimal Range] of [Far], and you try to hit a target that is [Nearby], the DL is raised by one. To hit a target that is [Close] would mean the DL is raised by two.

docs.title: Out of Ammo
docs.text: Some tricks result in you running [Out of Ammo] on a Face or Glitch. If you are using a [Firearm] when you run [Out of Ammo], you must spend 1 AP to use that weapon again. If you are controlling a [Drone] when you run [Out of Ammo], you must recover the drone and then spend 1 AP to use its weapon again.

docs.title: Perfect Balance
docs.text: If you have [Perfect Balance], you cannot gain [Off Balance].

docs.title: Physical
docs.text: When you use this trick, you physically interact with something or someone in the world.

docs.title: Range
docs.text: This trick is affected by the distance between you and the target. There are three types of [Range]: [Close], [Nearby], and [Far].

docs.title: Reaction
docs.text: This trick is used in response to a trigger defined in its description. When the condition for the trigger occurs, you may use this trick even if it's not your turn. [Reaction] actions are free and do not have an AP cost. However, you can only use a number of [Reaction] actions each turn equal to your Agility score.

docs.title: Recoil
docs.text:
A [Firearm] with [Recoil] is more difficult to shoot multiple times on the same turn. When you use a weapon with [Recoil], every [Attack] you make beyond the first with the same weapon on the same turn has its Difficulty Level raised by one. This DL increase is cumulative. [Recoil] is a [Weapon Type] characteristic and is found on Heavy Pistols, Rifles, Shotguns, and SMGs.

For example, the Desert Viper is a Heavy Pistol, which means it has the [Recoil] trait. The first shot with the Desert Viper using the Single Shot trick has a DL of Moderate (14). The second shot (with Single Shot) on the same turn has a DL of Hard (20), and the third shot has a DL of Severe (26).

docs.title: Reduced
docs.text:
To determine [Reduced] damage, use the next worse value from the weapon's [Damage Array] compared to the damage generated by the outcome of the roll. [Reduced] damage cannot be lower than 1.

In other words, [Maximum Damage] is [Reduced] to [Normal Damage], [Normal Damage] is [Reduced] to [Minimum Damage], and [Minimum Damage] is [Reduced] to [Absolute Damage].

docs.title: Rifle
docs.text: [Rifle] is both a [Weapon Type]. The [Rifle] weapon type includes the following keywords: [Firearm], [Recoil], and [Two Hands].

docs.title: Rifles
docs.text: [Rifles] is a [Weapon Group] which contains the following [Weapon Types]: [Rifle].

docs.title: SMG
docs.text: [SMG] is a [Weapon Type]. It belongs to the [Light Arms] weapon group. The [SMG] weapon type includes the following keywords: [Firearm], [One Hand], [Recoil], and [Spray].

docs.title: Secret
docs.text: Some tricks give you a [Secret] when you roll a Cool Success. A [Secret] has a few uses. First, it can be used to obtain a piece of important information related to your roll. If the GM has information to share that would satisfy the [Secret], they can offer it to you immediately. However, you can choose to bank the [Secret] instead and spend it later. A [Secret] may be spent at any time to ask the GM one Yes/No question related to the topic or context of your original roll. The GM must answer truthfully, though they may ask you to rephrase the question. Last, you may spend a [Secret] to lower the DL of any roll regardless of whether it is related to your original roll or not.

docs.title: Security
docs.text: [Security] is a measure of how secure something is. It can be used to define the difficulty of hacking a device or system, but it can also refer to the overall defense posture of a defined area, like an office building or a region of airspace. [Security] is expressed as a Difficulty Level. Retail is Easy (8), Small Corp Grade is Moderate (14), Middle Corp Grade is Hard (20), Megacorp Grade is Severe (26), and Milsec Grade is Extreme (32).

docs.title: Security Alert
docs.text:
A [Security Alert] is issued when an intruder is detected by a device, system, or person, such as a guard calling in an alert.

In the case of a device or system, a [Security Alert] is issued when a hacker is detected. It forcibly dumps the user that triggered the [Security Alert] and notifies the [Admin], as well as possibly executing a lockdown process and reporting the user's physical location to the appropriate security personnel.

When an intruder is detected at a physical location, the response varies based on its defense capabilities. A retail store will likely just autodial local law enforcement, whereas a megacorp is sure to have an array of resources and techniques it can choose from when forming its response.

docs.title: Short Blade
docs.text: [Short Blade] is a [Weapon Type]. It belongs to the [Bladed] weapon group. The [Short Blade] weapon type includes the following keywords: [Concealable], [Melee], and [One Hand].

docs.title: Shotgun
docs.text: [Shotgun] is a [Weapon Type]. It belongs to the [Light Arms] weapon group. The [Shotgun] weapon type includes the following keywords: [Firearm], [Recoil], [Spread], and [Two Hands].

docs.title: Signature Trick
docs.text: Signature tricks are specialized uses of your skills They represent advanced techniques that a person could not reasonably intuit their way through. They require special training and practice. Signature tricks work just like core tricks except you can only use a signature trick if your character has learned it. New characters start the game with two signature tricks selected during character creation. You can learn new signature tricks by purchasing them with XP.

docs.title: Skill Bonus
docs.text: Each of your skills can have a skill bonus (up to +3). Add your skill bonus to your roll when you use a trick governed by that skill. New characters start the game with a +1 bonus to a few skills. Later, once you've played the game and been award some experience points (XP), you can spend those points to pick up a +1 bonus in a new skill or increase an existing bonus (up to +3). This is covered in the Experience Points section of these rules.

docs.title: Small Arms
docs.text: The [Small Arms] [Weapon Group] contains the following Weapon Types: Light Pistol, Heavy Pistol, Shotgun, and SMG.

docs.title: Small Item
docs.text: Represents an item small enough to fit in the palm of your hand, such as a ring, wristwatch, or data disk.

docs.title: Social
docs.text: This trick is used to interact with people. Unless otherwise indicated, you must be [Close] to your opponent to use a [Social] trick on them.

docs.title: Spray
docs.text:
When you make an [Attack] using Burst Fire or Full Auto, you can use [Spray] to hit multiple targets that are [Close] to one another. Burst Fire can be used to hit one additional target (two total), and Full Auto can be used to hit up to four additional targets (five total). When you use [Spray], divide the damage equally between the targets. If the damage cannot be divided equally, any remainder is lost.

For example, you use Burst Fire to make an [Attack] with your Uzog Mini Mk-9 SMG. You opt to use [Spray] because there are two targets standing [Close] to one another. You make your Firearms roll to use Burst Fire and score a Fade, which deals [Minimum Damage]. The Uzog's [Damage Array] for Burst Fire is 10/20/50, so the [Minimum Damage] is 10. This number is divided evenly between the two targets, so they each take 5 damage.

docs.title: Spread
docs.text:
When you make an [Attack] with a shotgun, it uses [Spread] to hit multiple targets that are [Close] to one another. To determine which targets are hit, first identify the primary target. Then, look for additional targets that are [Close] to the primary and which are not behind [Cover, Full] or [Cover, Partial] (including being behind other people). [Spread] can affect up to two additional targets, and you cannot choose to avoid hitting them. If the outcome of the [Attack] damage to the primary target, it deals [Reduced](/../[Keywords/Keyword_Reduced)]] damage to each additional target as well. You cannot choose to avoid hitting additional targets.

Also, a weapon with [Spread] cannot be used to [Attack] targets at [Far] range.

For example, you use a Graham H6 shotgun to make an [Attack] against a target. There are two additional targets standing [Close] to the first (primary) target. You make your Firearms roll to use Single Shot and score a Success, which deals [Normal Damage]. The H6's [Damage Array] for Single Shot is 9/18/45, so the [Normal Damage] is 18. The primary target takes 18 points of damage. The two additional targets take damage from the next step down on the [Damage Array], which is [Minimum Damage]. The H6's [Minimum Damage] is 9, so the two additional targets each take 9 points of damage.

docs.title: Stability
docs.text: This trait represents the overall balance and mass of a [Vehicle] and is used to resist being pushed around on the road. [Stability] is expressed as a Difficulty Level.

docs.title: Stabilization DL
docs.text: Your [Stabilization DL] is based on your Resilience score. Resilience of 5 (or higher) means you have a [Stabilization DL] of Easy (8). Resilience of 4 means you have a [Stabilization DL] of Moderate (14). Resilience of 3 means you have a [Stabilization DL] of Hard (20). Resilience of 2 means you have a [Stabilization DL] of Severe (26). Resilience of 1 means you have a [Stabilization DL] of Extreme (32).

docs.title: Strap In
docs.text: When you [Strap In], you get into the driver's seat of a vehicle equipped with an onboard [Control Deck], and you connect it to the Control Port augment in the back of your head. In this configuration, you use your body, your arms and legs, your eyes and ears, just like an unaugmented driver, but your movements and senses are enhanced, supercharged, by the vehicle's [Control Deck]. Data bleeds into your view of the street. Digital timers, targeting reticules, and distance markers litter your view, yet somehow your brain absorbs the information they provide, improving your performance.

docs.title: Stunning Look
docs.text: While wearing a [Stunning Look] in its matching social environment (Street, City, Underworld, Milsec, or Corporate), the DL of Persuade rolls is lowered by one. A [Stunning Look] can be created with a Wardrobe, High End.

docs.title: Supplies
docs.text: This trick requires materials worth 100 cred (which are consumed upon use)

docs.title: Surgical Procedure
docs.text: An invasive medical procedure, usually performed to treat an injury or install cyberware. A [Surgical Procedure] takes between 30 and 90 minutes from start to finish. As a general rule, a minor procedure takes 30 minutes, a moderate procedure takes 60 minutes, and a major procedure takes 90 minutes.

docs.title: Temporary
docs.text: Some tricks can grant a character a [Temporary] benefit. Once you use the [Temporary] benefit, it is gone. If you end your turn with a [Temporary] benefit, you lose that [Temporary] benefit.

docs.title: Threat
docs.text: [Threat] is an NPC trait that ranges from +1 to +20 and represents an NPC's overall competence and the danger they pose to the player characters. The GM adds the NPC's [Threat] bonus to all rolls made for that NPC. An NPC's max hit points are equal to their [Threat] x 5.

docs.title: Tools
docs.text: This skill action requires tools worth 200 cred (which are retained upon use).

docs.title: Trick
docs.text: A trick is a specific use of a skill. Each skill includes [Core Tricks] and [Signature Tricks] Core tricks and signature tricks include their own rules and their own outcomes. When a player wants to try something not covered by the rules, the GM can allow it as an [Improvised Trick].

docs.title: Two-Handed Grip
docs.text: Light Pistols and Heavy Pistols can be fired using a [Two-Handed Grip] to improve accuracy. This requires [Two Hands]. When using [Two-Handed Grip], the DL is lowered by one.

docs.title: Two Hands
docs.text: You must must both hands.

docs.title: Unarmed
docs.text: [Unarmed] is a [Weapon Type]. It belongs to the [Blunt Force] weapon group. The [Unarmed] weapon type includes the following keywords: [Brawl] and [Two Hands].

docs.title: Unarmed Strike
docs.text:
Indicates an [Attack] made without weapons, such as a punch or kick. See the [Unarmed Strike] trick for more information.

The [Damage Array] for [Unarmed Strike] uses your Strength score for [Minimum Damage], Strength x 2 for [Normal Damage], and Strength x 5 for [Maximum Damage].

docs.title: Upgraded
docs.text: When an Outcome is [Upgraded], it is improved by one level. That is, a Glitch becomes a Fade, a Fade becomes a Success, and a Success becomes a Cool Success. A Cool Success cannot be [Upgraded].

docs.title: Vehicle
docs.text: A [Vehicle] is an electric conveyance, such as a car, truck, or motorcycle. A [Vehicle] has the following traits: [Handling], [Stability], and [Security].

docs.title: Vicinity
docs.text: This trick tracks the proximity of people to one another. Indoors, you and another person are in the same [Vicinity] if you are [Nearby], such as in the same a room, hallway, etc. Outdoors, the [Vicinity] is limited to being [Close] to the other person.

docs.title: Visible
docs.text: When you use this trick, other people must be able to see you.

docs.title: Visual
docs.text: You must be able to see to use this trick.

docs.title: Vocal
docs.text: When you use this trick, you use your voice.

docs.title: Weapon Groups
docs.text:
A [Weapon Group] is a collection of [Weapon Types].

There are four [Weapon Groups]: [Blades], [Blunt Force], [Small Arms], and [Rifles].

Weapon Groups are used by Armor.

docs.text: To use this trick, your device (and the target device if there is one) must be connected to the wireless Net.

docs.text: [Wits] is an NPC trait that represents their intelligence, awareness, and critical thinking. When a player uses a trick to manipulate or deceive an NPC, they roll against the NPC's [Wits].. [Wits] is expressed as a Difficulty Level.

docs.title: Folding Stock
docs.text: A [Folding Stock] is built into or attached to a firearm and helps reduce [Recoil]. It can be deployed or folded in combat by spending 1 AP. When deployed, your second [Attack] with the same weapon on the same turn ignores [Recoil]. If you make a third [Attack], [Recoil] is applied. If a weapon with a [Folding Stock] is also [Concealable], it loses the [Concealable] quality while the [Folding Stock] is deployed. [Folding Stock] does not stack with [Gas Vents].

docs.title: Gas Vents
docs.text:
This [Firearm] includes [Gas Vents] which help reduce [Recoil]. There are two levels of [Gas Vents]: Gas Vents 1 and Gas Vents 2. Gas Vents 2 is an upgraded version and replaces Gas Vents 1; they do not stack.

  • Gas Vents 1 - Your second [Attack] with the same weapon on the same turn ignores [Recoil]. If you make a third [Attack], [Recoil] is applied.

  • Gas Vents 2 - Your second and third [Attack] with the same weapon on the same turn both ignore [Recoil].

For example, the PX-90 comes with [Gas Vents 1], and it is a Rifle, which means it has the [Recoil] trait. The first shot with the PX-90 using the [Burst Fire] trick has a DL of Hard (20). The second shot with Burst Fire on the same turn also has a DL of Hard (20) because Gas Vents 1 causes you to ignore [Recoil] on the second shot. The third shot with Burst Fire has a DL of Severe (26) because [Recoil] takes effect and raises the Difficulty Level.

docs.title: Gunwire Grip
docs.text:
A [Gunwire Grip] is built into or attached to the grip of a firearm. This weapon mod grants a +2 [Gear Bonus] to Firearms, but only if the wielder has the [Gunwires] augment.

A [Gunwire Grip] can be configured so the firearm is locked and unusable by anyone except for those with authorized biometrics.

docs.title: Laser Sight
docs.text: A [Laser Sight] is built into or attached to a firearm. When turned on, a [Laser Sight] creates a thin, barely visible beam of light that puts a colored dot (usually red or green) on the target, making it easier to hit. You gain a +1 [Gear Bonus] to Firearms when using a [Laser Sight].

docs.title: Scope
docs.text:
A [Scope] extends the effective [Optimal Range] of a [Firearm] and helps you hit distant targets. A [Scope] can only be attached to a Heavy Pistol or Rifle. When you use a weapon with a [Scope] to make an [Attack], the weapon's [Optimal Range] extends to include the next farther [Range]. If the weapon's [Optimal Range] is already [Far], then a [Scope] extends its [Optimal Range] to include targets beyond [Far] range. This is the only way to make an [Attack] on a target at extreme distances beyond [Far] range.

For example, a Ranco .357 Equalizer has an [Optimal Range] of [Nearby]. Attaching a [Scope] to this weapon would mean [Nearby] and [Far] are both treated as being at [Optimal Range]. A Salvati Duro Carbine has an [Optimal Range] of [Far], so its [Scope] means a target at [Far] [Range] or beyond would be treated as being in [Optimal Range].

docs.title: Silencer
docs.text: A [Silencer] is built into or attached to a firearm. It reduces the muzzle flash and noise caused by firing the weapon. Attempts to notice gunfire from this weapon have their DL raised by one.

docs.title: Underbarrel Flashlight
docs.text: An [Underbarrel Flashlight] is built into or attached to a firearm. When turned on, an [Underbarrel Flashlight] illuminates everything [Nearby] with a bright, white light, which eliminates the [Dark] condition from that area. Additionally, anyone in the illuminated area has difficulty seeing you, as the bright light obscures their vision. You have [Concealment, Partial] against them.

docs.title: Adjusting the Difficulty Level
docs.text: Before the roll, the GM should adjust the DL based on relevant conditions, NPC's attitudes, and environmental effects.

docs.title: Raising and Lowering the DL
docs.text:
When you adjust the DL, you move up or down an entire Difficulty Level tier. That is, if the DL is Moderate (14) and something causes the DL to be raised by one, the DL goes to Hard (20) because that is the next step up in the Difficulty Level chart. If the DL is Moderate (14) and something causes it to be lowered, it goes to Easy (8) because that is the next step down in the chart.

Difficulty Level DL Range Extreme (32) 32 - 37 Severe (26) 26 - 31 Hard (20) 20 - 25 Moderate (14) 14 - 19 Easy (8) 8 - 13

These five Difficulty Levels, Easy (8), Moderate (14), Hard (20), Severe (26), and Extreme (32), are the only DLs you will ever use in this game. You will never apply a +1 to a DL causing it to be 9, for example. When a DL is raised or lowered, it moves a full increment up or down the chart.

docs.title: Easy (8) and Extreme (32)
docs.text:
The level below Easy (8) is considered trivial. If the DL is Easy (8) and a trick or effect lowers it, the GM can rule that no roll is necessary because the action is so trivial, it carries no risk. Otherwise, the DL stays at Easy (8).

The level above Extreme (32) is considered impossible. If the DL is Extreme (32) and a trick or effect raises it, the GM can rule that the action is simply not possible for the character. Otherwise, the DL stays at Extreme (32).

docs.title: Conditions
docs.text: Conditions like [Wounded], [Distracted], and [Inspired] raise or lower the DL on rolls you make. Conditions are described in their own section later in this book. If a character is under the effects of multiple conditions that alter the DL, they all apply.

docs.title: Environmental Effects
docs.text: When the environment could negatively influence the outcome of a roll, refer to the appropriate conditions in these rules. Some tricks are more difficult to pull off successfully when it is [Raining], [Foggy], [Windy] or [Dark]. To keep things quick, the GM can eschew these specific conditions and decide to simply raise the DL by one anytime there are one or more environmental effects that make a trick more difficult.

docs.title: Attitude
docs.text:
When you use a [Social] trick on an NPC, their [Attitude] towards you can raise or lower the DL.

Attitude Effect Friendly Lowers the DL of your [Social] tricks by one Neutral No effect Hostile Raises the DL of your [Social] tricks by one

docs.title: Setting the Difficulty Level
docs.text:
Each trick described in these rules includes an entry for Difficulty Level (DL). The Difficulty Level for a trick is usually either a static DL, or it is based on one of an NPC's traits. Occasionally, a trick eschews the typical DL framework by calling for an [Opposed] roll.

The only time the GM needs to set the DL themselves is when the rules don't cover the action a player wants their character to take. If the GM allows it, the player can roll it as an improvised trick, as described below.

docs.title: Difficulty Levels
docs.text:
Each Difficulty Level (DL) has a name and a number in parenthesis. When you make a roll, you compare the result (after applying bonuses) to the Difficulty Level to determine the outcome.

A Difficulty Level has a DL range associated with it, as shown below. For example, the DL range for Easy (8) goes from 8 to 13. The next Difficulty Level picks up where the last one stopped, so Moderate (14) goes from 14 to 19, and so on. Rolling above or below the target DL range changes the outcome of your roll, as described under Outcomes below.

There are five Difficulty Levels in this game: Easy (8), Moderate (14), Hard (20), Severe (26), and Extreme (32).

Difficulty Level DL Range Extreme (32) 32 - 37 Severe (26) 26 - 31 Hard (20) 20 - 25 Moderate (14) 14 - 19 Easy (8) 8 - 13

docs.title: NPC Traits as Difficulty Levels
docs.text:
Some tricks use one of an NPC's trait as the base Difficulty Level. For example, Persuade (Convince) uses your opponent's Wits for the DL and Hacking (Street Hack) uses the [Security] rating of the target device.

Traits are expressed as Difficulty Levels. For example, Rico the food cart vendor has a Wits of Moderate (14), and the local Food Mart's payment system has a [Security] of Hard (20).

docs.title: Static DL
docs.text: Some tricks simply state the DL to use. For example, Insight (Size Up Opponent) has a DL of Moderate (14).

docs.title: Opposed Rolls
docs.text: Occasionally, the rules call for an [Opposed] roll, which means both you and the GM roll (and add your bonuses) and then compare your results to determine the outcome. As such, [Opposed] rolls do not use Difficulty Levels.

docs.title: Improvised Tricks
docs.text: When these rules do not cover the action a player wants their character to perform, the GM can declare it an improvised trick. The GM sets the DL using their best judgement. Refer to the DL chart above and use one of the standard five Difficulty Levels: Easy (8), Moderate (14), Hard (20), Severe (26), and Extreme (32).

docs.title: Luck Points
docs.text: Luck Points can give you bonuses to your rolls and help you avoid glitches, as described below. You start the game with one Luck Point.

docs.title: Spending a Luck Point
docs.text:
To use a Luck Point you must declare to the GM and the other players that you are using a Luck Point and how you are using it. There are two ways to use a Luck Point: 1) Get a Luck Bonus to a roll; and 2) Avoid a Glitch.

For example, "Dang, I rolled a glitch. I'll use a Luck Point to avoid it," or "I just missed a Success on this roll, so I'll use a Luck Point to get a +2 Luck Bonus. That bumps me up to a Success!"

docs.title: Luck Bonus
docs.text: After you Make a Roll, you can spend a Luck Point to get a +2 Luck Bonus to your result, or a +3 Luck Bonus if you're using a favored skill.

docs.title: Avoid a Glitch
docs.text: If you roll a Glitch, you can spend a Luck Point to [Upgrade] the outcome to a Fade.

docs.title: Recovering Luck Points
docs.text: At the start of each game session, your character recovers all of the Luck Points they previously spent. Some tricks and other effects can make you [Lucky], which causes you to recover a Luck Point mid-session.

docs.title: Buy Luck Points
docs.text: In addition to the Luck Point you get at the start of the game, you can purchase up to two additional Luck Points for 10 XP each. You cannot have more than three Luck Points at any time. Luck Points you purchase are permanent additions to your character. They are spent and recovered as normal.

docs.title: Making a Roll
docs.text:
When the GM determines that a roll is necessary, follow the steps below.

  1. Skill - First, identify the skill to use based on what the character is trying to do. For example, use the Firearms skill to shoot a gun and the Athletics skill to make a running jump. If you have a bonus in the selected skill, it is added to your roll.

  2. Ability Score - The skill determines the ability score to use for the roll. For example, the Firearms skill uses Agility. You will add this ability score to your roll.

  3. Trick - Determine which of the skill's tricks to use. You can use any of the skill's core tricks or a signature trick if you know one that applies. If you want to do something these rules don't cover, your GM may allow it as an improvised trick.

  4. Difficulty Level - The trick specifies the Difficulty Level for the roll. The GM adjusts the Difficulty Level up or down, as described in Adjusting the Difficulty Level.

  5. Roll 2d10 - Roll 2d10 (two ten-sided dice) and sum them together. For example, if you rolled a 2 on one die and a 9 on the other die, you would have rolled 11.

  6. Ability Score and Skill Bonus - Add the primary ability score based for the skill you're using. If you have a skill bonus, add that too. For example, the Firearms skill is associated with Agility. If your character has an Agility score of 3 and a +1 skill bonus in Firearms, you would add +4 to your Firearms roll.

  7. Gear and Aug Bonuses - If you have a gear bonus from a piece of equipment or an aug bonus from a cybernetic augmentation or psionic mutation, add those as well. For example, using a laser sight grants a +1 gear bonus to Firearms rolls. Bonuses of the same type do not stack, as described below.

  8. Result of the Roll - The sum of your dice roll, plus your ability score and your bonuses is called the result.

  9. Luck Bonus - After you roll the dice and determine the result, you can spend a Luck Point to add a Luck Bonus to the result.

  10. Outcome - Compare the result to the outcomes chart in the description of the trick you used to determine what happens.

Making a Roll 2d10 + Ability Score + Skill Bonus + Gear Bonus + Aug Bonus = Result (+ Luck Bonus)

docs.title: Stacking Bonuses
docs.text:
For any roll, you add at most one ability score, one skill bonus, one gear bonus, one aug bonus, and one luck bonus. You always add one ability score, but you might not have all (or any) of these bonuses.

Bonuses of the same type that target the same skill do not stack, and only the highest one applies. For example, if you have two pieces of gear that both give a gear bonus to Firearms, only the higher of the two bonuses is applied.

docs.title: Substituting Ability Scores
docs.text:
Even though each skill has its own primary ability, the GM might decide to call for another ability to be used with a skill if it's appropriate.

For example, asking the player to roll Strength with Intimidate when they try to literally strongarm someone into compliance, or having the player roll Drive with Intelligence to see if they know the kind of battery used in a specific model car.

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text: When you roll for a skill or trick, there are four possible outcomes: Glitch, Fade, Success, and Cool Success.

docs.title: Universal Outcomes
docs.text:
Each trick's specific outcomes chart is modeled after the universal outcomes chart shown below. It shows how to determine if a result is a Glitch, Fade, Success, or Cool Success. The GM should also use this chart to adjudicate improvised tricks when they arise.

For the purpose of determining outcomes, treat the range from 2 - 7 as a Trivial DL and 39+ as an Impossible DL. This framework allows for a Fade on an Easy (8) DL, a Glitch on a Moderate (14) DL, and a Cool Success on an Extreme (32) DL.

Rolling double 10s on 2d10 automatically results in a Cool Success.

Outcome Roll Description Glitch Falls in the DL range two or more levels lower The task failed with a complication Fade Falls in the DL range one level lower The task was completed successfully but with a complication Success Hits the DL range The task was completed successfully Cool Success Over the DL range The task was completed successfully and with an extra benefit

docs.title: Trick Outcomes
docs.text:
When you use a trick included in these rules, you should use the specific outcomes chart included in its description. Each trick has its own outcomes chart but the structure of the four outcomes always follows the universal outcomes shown above. As an example, the outcomes chart for the Persuade (Haggle) signature trick is shown below.

Outcome Description Glitch You get 20% worse price and their [Attitude] worsens Fade You get 20% better price and their [Attitude] worsens Success You get 20% better price Cool Success You get 20% better price and a [Gift]

For example, a player rolls Persuade (Haggle) with a DL of Moderate (14). After applying bonuses, their roll results in a 15. This is a Success because the result falls inside the DL range for Moderate (14), which is 14-19.

docs.title: Opposed Outcomes
docs.text:
When the rules call for an [Opposed] roll (or when the GM decides an [Opposed] roll is appropriate), you and the GM both roll, add your bonuses, and compare results. Tricks that use [Opposed] rolls have their own specific outcomes. When the GM declares an action to be an improvised trick, they should refer to the chart below to determine the outcome of the contest.

Outcome Roll Description Glitch Lower than the GM's roll The task failed with a complication Fade Equals the GM's roll The task was completed successfully but with a complication Success 1-5 higher than the GM's roll The task was completed successfully Cool Success 6+ higher than the GM's roll The task was completed successfully and with an extra benefit For example, a player wants their character to use Brawl (Grapple) on an opponent. This is an [Opposed] roll, so both the GM and the player roll. After applying their bonuses, the GM's result is 9 and the player's result is 12. This is a Success because 12 is 1-5 higher than the GM's result which was 9.

docs.title: Turn Etiquette
docs.text:
Players should generally avoid interrupting other players on their turns. However, if one player narrates an action that would directly impact another player, the GM may allow the second player to react directly before returning to the first player. Any reaction by a second player should be minimal to preserve the first player's turn.

If you are unsure of what to do on your turn, the GM may also prompt you with a question or two to help you identify possible actions your character could take. However, you are not required to take an action on your turn. You may pass.

docs.title: Turn Length
docs.text: Whether you are working with regular turns or combat turns, the players and GM should strive to keep the game moving. Players should expect each turn to last no more than five minutes. The only real exception to this is group turns, which can last considerably longer if the entire crew is together. However, if one or two characters are off doing their own thing individually while the rest have a group turn together, the general rule of five minutes per turn stands. The GM should always be cognizant of all players at the table and try to make sure everyone gets the opportunity to act.

docs.title: Turn Order
docs.text:
Each time your group assembles, whether online or in person, to play the game, the GM will start by setting the stage, reminding everyone of the events of last session, and so on.

Play begins with the player to the GM's left. They describe what their character does, and the GM responds accordingly. Then, play proceeds to the left and the next player takes a turn, and so on, until everyone has taken a turn, and play comes back to the GM.

It is not necessary to maintain the same turn order from session to session, and players are free to choose different seats at the start of each session. On the other hand, some groups may prefer a consistent order and will choose to keep their same seats every session.

docs.title: Types of Turns
docs.text: There are four types of turns in this game: out-of-combat turns, combat turns, group turns, and GM turns. This game makes no mechanical distinction between out-of-combat and in-combat turns. However, it may be easier to think of turns that way.

docs.title: Out-of-Combat Turns
docs.text:
During an out-of-combat turn, you might tell the GM your character wants to sneak into the warehouse you learned about from your contact. The GM sets the scene, and you describe what your character is doing. You decide to hop the fence, and the GM calls for an Athletic Move roll (1 AP). As you cautiously approach the warehouse, the GM calls for a Sneak roll (1 AP) to avoid being noticed by the patrolling guards. Last, you use Disable Device (1 AP) to override the electronic lock on the door. Those three actions used your 3 AP. If you want to go inside and explore further, you'll have to wait until your next turn.

The GM is not required to call for any rolls during your turn, and it's important to remember When to Roll. Out-of-combat turns can feel less structured than combat turns and rely on both the GM and player to regulate the amount of time spent.

docs.title: Combat Turns
docs.text: During a combat turn, the types of actions may be different, but the process works the same way. If you [Move] to an area [Nearby] (1 AP), draw your weapon (1 AP), and use Burst Fire to attack an enemy (1 AP), you have spent a total of 3 AP, and your turn ends. At the start of your next turn, your AP will refresh, and you can take three more actions.

docs.title: Group Turns
docs.text:
When the group is partially or completely together in the same place at the same time, the GM is free to drop individual turns in favor of group turns. Group turns offer a loose, collaborative segment in which players share their ideas and narrate their character's actions without a formal turn order. This is a great time to let the players show off their characters' personalities and quirks, and it lets them roleplay with one another.

Group turns are especially useful when time is compressed or actions are routine, such as when the characters travel together across the city, a trip that could take a couple of hours or more. If players prefer to stay in the round robin turn order during group scenes, that is perfectly fine. Some players may want the opportunity to narrate what their character is doing during this moment of downtime.

Anyone not part of these group turns should still be given their individual turns, whether regular or combat.

docs.title: GM Turns
docs.text: When play comes back to the GM, it signals a potential escalation. The GM can use their turn to introduce new characters into a scene, whether in combat or not. The GM should also use their turn to run the opposition against those who are in combat.

docs.title: Round Robin: The Flow of the Game
docs.text:
This game uses a round robin turn-taking style for all scenes and actions, including those in combat and out of combat. In fact, in terms of player facetime with the GM, this game makes no distinction between combat and non-combat turns.

It is possible for some players to be in combat while other players are not. This does not alter the turn order. The game will always proceed in a round robin manner, even if that means you end up with a mix, such as, one player takes a turn in combat, the next player takes a turn outside of combat, and the last player takes a turn in a different combat.

This game is designed to allow players to have their characters act independently from one another without forcing anyone to "sit out" until one group's actions have been resolved. Instead, this game blends everyone's actions together in an orderly way by requiring everyone to take turns.

docs.title: Your Turn
docs.text: On your turn, you tell the GM what you want your character to do. You can also ask questions of the GM or other players, whether their characters are with you or not. While in-game actions and dice rolls are shared openly, players are expected to keep their characters' knowledge separate. Just because you heard it, doesn't mean your character did.

docs.title: Action Points
docs.text: At the start of your turn, you get 3 Action Points (AP), which you can spend to take actions, such to Move, or use a trick. On your turn, each action you take costs 1 AP. You cannot save AP turn over turn. If you decide to end your turn without spending all three AP, you lose the remainder (though they will refresh as normal at the start of your next turn).

docs.title: End of the Action
docs.text: After the outcome of an action has been determined, that action is over. If the player has more action points, they may spend them to do more things. Otherwise, the player's turn is over and the next player's turn starts.

docs.title: When to Roll
docs.text:
When a player describes what their character is doing, the GM first determines if a roll is necessary. If the task is trivial, impossible, or carries no risk, such that a character could keep trying until they were successful, then it is not necessary to roll.

Task Resolution Examples Trivial You succeed Open a doorMake a phone callLog on to the Net Impossible You cannot attempt Jump over a houseRun across waterAccess cyberspace without jacking in No Risk Keep trying until you succeed Climb over a small fenceNavigate to an unfamiliar destinationRepair a piece of broken equipment

It's important to realize that the same task can be performed automatically when there is no risk but requires a roll when there is. For example, climbing over a small fence is relatively easy to do but still requires some effort. All else being equal, a character could keep trying until they succeed; no need to roll. However, that same task requires a roll if we introduce risk.

For example, a character is being chased and rounds the corner to see a small fence blocking their path. Now. if the character decides to go over the fence, the GM should have the player roll, even if the task is easy, Rolling low means the player might get a Fade, which introduces a complication, or a Glitch, which means they simply failed. In this example, failing to climb the fence means the pursuers get have a chance to catch up.

docs.title: Skills and Tricks
docs.text:
Skills and Tricks

There are fifteen skills in this game, three for each of the core five abilities (Presence, Awareness, Agility, Intelligence, and Strength). For example, the three skills associated with Agility are Drive, Firearms, and Stealth.

If your character knows a skill, it will have a skill bonus ranging from +1 to +3. When you make a roll with a skill, you add your skill bonus and the skill's primary ability score to the roll.

The skills in this game include rules for tricks, which are specific uses of a skill. For example, the Medicine skill includes a trick called First Aid and another called Surgery.

Tricks are categorized as being either core tricks or signature tricks. Anyone may use core tricks, even if they have no skill bonus, but you can only use a signature trick if your character knows it.

When a player wants to try something not covered by the rules, the GM can allow them to perform an improvised trick.

Refer to the Skills and Tricks List for a full list of skills and tricks included in this game.

docs.text:

You utilize your incredible balance and speed to execute a death defying climb, jump, or dive.

Use Acrobatic Stunt to [Move] beyond a significant physical obstacle or to gain access to a hard-to-reach area. When you use this trick, state the desired outcome of your [Move], such as I want to move across the wire like a tightrope walker or I want to scale the sheer surface of this building.

docs.text:

You catch an object as it's falling or that was thrown to you.

When an object is thrown to you or falls [Close] to you, you can use a [Reaction] to Catch it. If you use only [One Hand], raise the DL by one. If the object is difficult to catch due to its size, weight, or other factors, the GM may raise the DL by one or simply state that it is not possible.

When you use Sprint, you must [Move] in a straight line.

You swiftly and silently close in on your opponent and execute a maneuver to quietly subdue them before they have time to react.

docs.text:

You know this city like the back of your hand.

When you use City Culture, you ask the GM a question related to the city you're in. For example, discovering a clue may lead you to ask, What do I know about the PRISM nightclub? or What is the '12th Annual Rose Festival' that we read about? Have I ever heard of that before? For example, an encounter with the Yakuza may make you wonder, What interest does the Yakuza have in Knifepoint Capital? or Who is in charge of the Yakuza in this city? The scope of this trick is limited to information about organized criminal enterprise, organization hierarchy and membership, and areas of influence.

docs.text:
Difficulty Level (DL) Skill Keywords Hard (20) Deception [Advanced Supplies], [Physical], [Supplies], [Two Hands]

Using clothing, makeup, and props, you create a disguise that makes you unrecognizable.

When you use Disguise, you use [Supplies] or [Advanced Supplies] to create the desired look. [Advanced Supplies] allow you replicate another person's appearance and raise the DL by one. This trick takes one hour to complete. If you rush, raise the DL by one and it takes 30 minutes.

You use special tools and materials to fabricate a forgery designed to fool people into thinking it's the real thing.

When you use Forgery, you use [Tools] and [Advanced Supplies] to create a replica of a mundane, non-electronic object. This trick takes an hour to complete. Replicating an object that is intricate or expensive raises the DL by one and takes 24 hours to complete, though those hours need not be consecutive.
